Your mercy flows—eternity—
Refreshing all my weary space.
O Sovereign King, my life, my home;
Thou art my God, and mine alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Before the dawn, I lift my gaze
To skies emblazoned, yet unknown,
A wanderer in silent praise.
The world in slumber cannot see
The fervent yearning of my heart—
Yet as the streams seek out the sea,
To Thee, my restless thoughts depart.
In wilderness, though lost I seem,
Your presence fills the empty air;
Each hope, each sorrow, each small dream
Is sheltered by Thy boundless care.
O God, my soul is Yours to own—
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Above the world, above its throne,
In quiet glades and noisy streets,
My searching heart Thy promise meets.
No idol fashioned by my hand,
No fleeting joy or shifting sand,
Could ever fill the ache inside
Where only You, my God, abide.
When darkness falls and doubts assail,
Your faithful presence will not fail.
I rest in love and mercy shown—
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Amidst the stars, amidst the stone,
No voice but Thine can answer me
Within this vast eternity.
In silent awe, my spirit kneels,
Above despair, beyond all fears,
For only You my hunger feels,
And gathers all my stinging tears.
From mountain path to weary plain,
Through joy and loss, through hope and pain,
Your everlasting hand has shown,
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
When all the world around has gone,
Still softly whispers in the night
Remind me I am in Thy sight.
No crown of gold, nor marble spire,
Competes with Thy eternal fire;
My every breath and secret thought
Is by Thy faithful hand begot.
Amid confusion, love has grown—
A seed in fields that You have sown;
I walk this journey, not my own,
O God! Thou art my God alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

text.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other voice I call my own.
When shadows loom and light is dim,
My trembling soul still clings to Him.
Upon the hills, beneath the sky,
Thy watchful care I can't deny.
In silence deep or songs of praise,
My heart is drawn through sacred ways,
To seek Thy truth, to feel Thy hand,
To know on Thee I ever stand.
So all my days, Thy love I'll own—
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Within the hush of night, I groan.
No idol shines or lifts my gaze,
Only Thy presence guides my days.
Through tempests wild and rivers deep,
Thou art the shepherd; I, the sheep.
No stranger voice can lead me far,
For in my darkness, Thou my star.
When doubt assails and hope seems flown,
Still, O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
In stillness or in tempest blown,
My soul has yearned, my heart has known
A refuge found in Thee alone.
The world may dazzle, kingdoms rise,
But none can match the boundless skies
Where mercy spreads and grace has flown—
O God! Thou art my God alone.
When weary feet from wandering roam,
I find my peace in Thy true home,
Held softly, gently, by Thy throne:
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
From golden dawn till twilight's tone,
My spirit seeks Thy holy face,
And finds in Thee sustaining grace.
No shifting sand nor fleeting praise
Distracts my heart from endless days
Where only Thou canst fill the throne—
O God! Thou art my God alone.
From whispered prayer to shouted plea,
Thy love enfolds and carries me;
And so, my faith is carved in stone:
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My shelter when I'm cast and thrown.
Amidst the noise and ceaseless strife,
Your quiet truth becomes my life.
No silver gods or wooden kings
Can match the peace Your presence brings.
In every sorrow, joy, or pain,
My trust in You will still remain.
Above the clouds, beneath the stone—
O God! Thou art my God alone.
Forevermore, my voice will raise
A song of love, a psalm of praise.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

text.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
In silent dawn, my soul has known
The hush of stars, the breath of grace—
A yearning heart that seeks Thy face.

Amidst the noise and fleeting days,
My spirit bends in quiet praise.
Though shadows drift, Thy light remains,
A constant balm for all my pains.

The world may lose its fleeting charms,
Yet I am safe within Thy arms.
Forever near, and never gone—
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
A whisper breathed in twilight’s tone.
Above the rushing, world-worn crowd,
Your presence gentle, steadfast, proud.

My trembling hope, my silent plea,
My resting place, my mystery.
Though tempests rise and dreams have flown,
Still, I am Yours, and Yours alone.

Beneath the stars, my soul takes flight—
You are my guide, my strength, my light.
O God, in every dusk and dawn,
Thou art the love I lean upon.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Before the mountains found their throne,
Before the rivers learned to flow,
Your name is all I’ve yearned to know.

In shadowed vales, where fears reside,
You are my comfort, truth, and guide.
While fleeting hearts may come and go,
Your faithfulness is all I know.

Let every breath, and thought, and psalm
Rise up to You, a fragrant balm.
My heart, Your dwelling, love has sown—
O God! My soul is Yours alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
In midnight’s hush, my heart has grown
To seek the voice both fierce and mild—
A searching, wandering, wayward child.

Upon the heights, in valleys deep,
When anguished dreams refuse to sleep,
My cry for shelter finds its place
Within the longing of your grace.

Though all the world dissolves in mist,
One truth remains, a gentle fist—
Thou art my home, my flesh, my bone:
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Each trembling breath, each whispered moan,
Rises towards Your shining throne—
A harmony of hope unknown.

Beneath the burdens I have borne,
In joy, in sorrow, lost, forlorn,
My every path, my every stone
Tells me: I am not my own.

As morning breaks upon the land,
Your touch is near, Your voice at hand.
In solitude or midst the throng—
O God! To You my praise belongs.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

text.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
In silent dawns when shadows break,
My soul awakes to seek Thy throne,
With thirst no waters here can slake.
Through deserts dry, in starless nights,
Thy presence feeds my fainting heart;
Thy wings enfold me in their heights,
And hope revives, though torn apart.

In secret places, love’s refrain
Is whispered gently to my ear;
I rest on promises that remain,
Thy word is steadfast, ever near.
So while I breathe, Thy grace I own—
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No counterfeit can fill my soul,
No idol’s voice nor monarch’s throne,
Can claim the depths Thou wholly know’st.
When midnight falls and shadows press,
My mind recalls each pledge and plea;
Within Thy shelter I find rest,
And all my thirst is slaked by Thee.

Above the storm, Thy mercy rings,
The sunlight dances on the dew;
Creator of all wondrous things,
My dawn, my dusk, my hope renewed.
Each breath I draw is not my own—
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
When morning bends with golden grace,
I lift my heart before Thy throne
And seek the splendor of Thy face.
Though worlds may fade and moments flee,
And shifting tides the earth transform,
Unchanging love remains with me,
A guiding fire through cold and storm.

When silence drapes the evening air,
And dreams assemble soft and clear,
I find Thy whispers lingering there,
A solace driving out all fear.
No distance dims my heartfelt tone:
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Through corridor of ancient years,
Your mercy’s fragrance has been sown,
A balm for sorrow, joy for tears.
In wilderness where footsteps fail,
I cling to You, my guiding flame;
You write my story, veil by veil,
And call me gently by my name.

Before this world with splendor teems,
And after all is dust and bone,
You are the keeper of my dreams—
O God, Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Through every trial, joy, and loss,
I've wandered far, but always known
Your gentlest hand along my cross.
No echo from the mountains wild
Nor deepest depths beneath the sea
Could hide my heart—I'm still Your child—
Wherever, Lord, You find me be.

When silence reigns and stars appear,
My longing soul ascends Your light;
In every prayer and quiet tear,
You answer softly through the night.
So let my life its witness own—
O God! Thou art my God alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

text.response:
Rewind life and remember the golden threads—
A laughter echoing on a summer lawn,
The trembling hush when first the tears were shed,
And how the dusk would linger long past dawn.
Remember starlight scattered on a lake,
A whispered promise in the midnight breeze.
Old pages flutter, heartstrings softly ache;
We gather, holding moments none can seize.
Let every rewind conjure up the glow
Of youthful dreams and roads we chose to roam,
For memories are lanterns guiding slow—
With every recollection, we find home.

Rewind life and remember the flicker,
Of candle flames in a childhood room,
The soft murmur of stories, quicker—
To hush away the gathering gloom.
Do you recall the chestnut trees,
The garden laughter, skipping stones?
Or how we’d race against the breeze,
Years before we called them our own bones.
Time spins forward, a river in haste,
Yet memory swirls, refuses to sever,
As hearts, in quiet yearning, taste—
The sweet refrain of forever.

Rewind life and remember—
How gentle the hands of time could be,
Cradling us in sepia hours
Before the clamor of "ought to be."
Remember the sun on your cheek,
The thrill before a birthday wish,
The world new, in awe, unique,
Nothing taken, all to relish.
Nostalgia aches but does not chain—
We step again in winding streams,
Each footprint moist with sudden rain,
Rewriting long-forgotten dreams.

Rewind life and remember:
The scent of rain upon the earth,
How tiny hands reached, groping tender,
Towards trembling light and second birth.
Recall the faces painted bright
By dawn’s first touch behind your eyes—
How farewells melted into night,
Yet love endured, to your surprise.
Remember words you left unspoken,
The music drifting from the hall?
We are memories—a spell, unbroken;
To rewind is to recall it all.

Rewind life and remember—
The lull of distant lullabies,
Grass underneath barefoot days,
Soft sorrows carried on surprise.
Old photo boxes spill their secrets:
A crayon sun, a secret smile,
Moments lost but unforgotten,
Echoes carried through each mile.
The heart, the truest archivist,
Tells stories time cannot sever;
In memory’s gentle, plaintive mist,
We rewind life—remember, forever.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

text.response:
Rewind life and remember—
A flicker of leaves in early September,
Laughing in fields where the tall grasses bend,
Moments I thought would never end.
The ghost of a tune traced in sunlight,
Midnight confessions bathed in moonlight.
Rewind, the world moves frame by frame:
Faces and places no longer the same.
In memory’s theater, hearts play their parts—
Weaving lost threads through echoing hearts.
Rewind life and remember:
Each beat, each ember, each slant of December.
From cradle to skyline, the timeline unfurls—
Rewind, and remember the beauty of worlds.

Rewind life and remember
the laughter that burst on frozen lips,
echoing down glittering childhood streets.
How snow swirled in hunger for mittens and boots,
how every step imprinted a story into fresh morning.
Rewind—feel the pulse of summer afternoons,
sticky with sweetness and distant football cheers.
Remember chasing the sun until it tipped off the tired horizon,
your whole being swaddled in the hope that nothing would change.
But turn back—let memories pool in the quiet corners:
Pages of dusty journals, faces lined with time’s gentle hand.
Somehow, remembering shapes tomorrow,
as we press play, braver from loving what was.

Rewind life and remember
the violet hush before words found their form,
tiny hands that reached for the improbable stars.
Remember the heartbreaks, the hallelujahs—
silver threads binding joy and sorrow.
Time loops, a ribbon twined across moments:
a first dance, a lost friend’s voice, jasmine at dusk.
Rewind, let nostalgia clothe the present—
the sacred hush at waking, the ache at nightfall.
We are mosaics of remembrances,
bright shards from what once was and is no more.
To rewind is not to flee,
but to gather the petals scattered on memory’s floor,
weaving them gently into the story of now.

To rewind life and remember
is to peel open faded envelopes of sensation:
The prick of rain on a child’s bare scalp,
Eyes wide at the thunder, holding tight to a parent’s hand.
We lie in sunlit rooms, shadows shifting,
Yearning for voices that softened us from within.
Memory is a reel spinning in silent theaters—
Visions of love, slices of catastrophe, solace in shared smiles.
Rewind, and the dust of years whirls up—
Not as ghosts, but as lanterns lighting future steps.
What we recall is not only what was,
but a wish for what might yet be:
A promise made in the gentle hush of remembrance.

Rewind life and remember—
not in longing, but in gratitude’s grace:
The brush of wind upon an eager face,
the melody of a friend’s spontaneous laughter,
each faded photograph tucked within our days.
Remember the quiet ache of goodbyes,
the thunderous hope of every uncertain morning,
old dreams folded under the pillow of night.
Rewind, and the heart stitches sorrow and joy
into a tapestry more real than the passing years—
We are travelers, carrying the weight and wonder
of moments lost and found. To remember is to live twice:
once for the beauty, once for the wisdom,
finding ourselves, whole, in the act of looking back.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

text.response:
Rewind life and remember—the laughter in the waning sun, 
The dusty swing set creaking, childish races just begun. 
The days spilled out like marbles across a kitchen floor, 
Glistening moments gathered, then vanished evermore.
We store them in our pockets, those snapshots of the heart, 
Shelter them through seasons, never truly torn apart. 
Rewind, press play, recall them: gentle, near and tender—
Life’s joy and ache entwined, in the act of soft remember.

In the silence of the evening, memories start to float: 
A melody of yesteryears, a half-remembered note. 
Rewind life and remember; hold tight what made us whole—
Treasured fragments of the past, etched upon the soul.

Rewind life and remember—the crescendos and the lulls, 
How the world once spun in color, when hope was never dull. 
Worn sneakers on a playground, laughter’s echo soft and clear, 
Painted skies in summer dusk, a whispered wish to hear.
Moments flutter back like sparrows, nesting in the mind, 
Lost birthdays, found adventures, faces left behind. 
What would you relive, if you could turn the hands of time? 
The secret smiles, the gentle tears, the reason and the rhyme.
Rewind life and remember—a garden growing wild; 
Every memory a flower; every heartbreak, every child.
With gratitude and longing, let your heart be light as ember—
For joy awaits each time you dare to pause, rewind, remember.

Rewind life and remember:
The shiver of dawn on barefoot skin,
Grandfather’s stories curling through the air—
A thread in the vast translucent fabric.
The scattered sparkle of childhood marbles,
And the crackling laughter around tables,
Flashes of running in summer rain,
Carefree and unburdened, destined to remain.
In the slow film of memory, the reels glide and stammer:
First heartbeat, first heartbreak, last glimpse of wonder.
If you could wind the clock with longing hands,
Would you stop at every tenderness, every sharp demand?
Rewind life and remember—
Tomorrow borrows strength from yesterday—
And in that gentle backward glance,
We gather the pieces we never truly lose.

Rewind life and remember, as moonlight floods the floor—
The whispered dreams behind closed eyes, the wishes you once wore. 
Echoes shimmer in the golden dusk, like footprints in wet sand, 
A tapestry of tender days you still hold in your hand. 
Chase the laughter down the corridors, let sorrow softly mend,
Each thread of memory, wound tight and spun, a story without end.
Pause at corners warmed by sunlight, where hope refused to fade—
There, the heartbeat of your younger self still dances, unafraid. 
Rewind life and remember, when every second bloomed anew,
All your fleeting moments wait, still precious, still true.

Rewind life and remember:
The hush of twilight secrets shared,
Ink-stained fingers, paper dreams, and hearts that never cared
For endings, just beginnings wrapped in music’s fragile hue.
A father’s laugh, a mother’s lull—ghosts you never truly knew.
The clock rewinds on innocence, rewound with every sigh,
A scented breeze, a battered shoe, a worn and cherished sky.
Each heartbeat marks a chapter, each tear a gentle ember—
This is how we carry on: we rewind, and we remember.
So let the past dance softly, let the film inside you play,
For in remembering yesterday, you light the world today.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

text.response:
Rewind life and remember, gentle as the spring rain—
A flicker of laughter in the kindling of youth,
Footsteps echo on a sunlit lane,
Dreams, a tapestry, both worn and smooth.
We cradle the photos, the crayon drawings,
The hush of twilight on our favorite street.
Each memory calls us, softly prodding,
To gather the fragments, both bitter and sweet.
So pause in the passage, let nostalgia surrender
To moments that shimmer just out of reach.
Rewind life and remember: each ember
Burns brightly as lessons only time can teach.

Rewind life and remember—
The taste of summer air,
The laughter at the corners
Of kitchens filled with care.
Childhood in sepia tone,
Bare feet on tender grass,
Old songs on radios,
Echoes from the past.
We build our present quietly
With bricks shaped from before,
Moments stack like memories
Behind each closing door.
With hearts both light and tender
We breathe in every ember,
To cherish and surrender—
Rewind life and remember.

Rewind life and remember:
The scent of autumn leaves beneath your shoes,
The jangle of a bicycle bell as dusk slipped in,
Curls of smoke from fireside tales—
Laughter etched on the air, hands held tight,
Promises whispered beneath cotton-candy clouds.
Now, with the hush of time’s gentle hand,
We gather up the years like seashells in a basket,
Listening for echoes still humming with hope.
Though the path unwinds and futures beckon,
Let’s linger here, where the heart beats slow.
For every fleeting yesterday is a lantern in the dark—
Guiding, warming, whispering: Begin, again.

Rewind life and remember—the flicker of yesterday’s flame,
Footprints traced in silver dew along a sleepy lane.
Moments pressed between the pages, faded Polaroids and thread,
A dance of dust in golden sunbeams, all the words we never said.
Rewind past the echoes, the tumble of childlike dreams,
To teetering bikes, scraped knees, midnight ice creams.
Remember how laughter chimes, how bittersweet goodbye
Left echoes in the hallway, and a tear that didn’t dry.
In this silent space behind us, where heartbeats once were loud,
We gather every memory, our heads and spirits bowed.
Rewind life and remember—a gift from time’s own hand:
That every up and stumble made us exactly as we stand.

Rewind life and remember—the way the sun poured golden gloss
On days when time was endless, untouched by loss or frost.
Find the trail of vanished moments: a playground’s roar,
A whispered secret beneath blankets, a slammed bedroom door.
Hope was easy; fear, just a shadow crossing bright walls.
We thought we’d always have this: laughter in the halls,
Midnight conversations, the courage to dream wide.
But the reel unwinds relentless, the memories caught inside.
So pause within the hush—collect what still burns tender:
The kindness of an old friend, a song that called your name.
In remembering, let gentle color fill what grew asunder.
Rewind life, and remember—we’re never quite the same.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

text.response:
Rewind life and remember—
The snapshots flicker, trembling on cassette tape dreams.
Laughter caught behind bicycle handlebars,
The hush before summer thunderstorms,
Pieced-together fragments seeping, like sunlight, under the door.
Each moment a misplaced puzzle piece found
In sand-filled tennis shoes, in a parent’s hush-hummed lullaby.
Remember—the daring taste of rainwater,
How eyes used to widen at the world’s simplest secrets.
Now, patched together by the thread of memory,
We rewind, and remember:
All we have loved was never truly lost,
Just paused, awaiting a gentle nudge in the dark
to play again.

Rewind life and remember.
Childhood’s laughter caught in backyard swings,
The warmth of shattered sun through amber trees,
Waters running slow and golden at our feet.
We gather fragments—gentle as the hush before sleep—
Threads of stories woven through old hands.
Photographs curl at the edges, soft as the faces we miss,
And in each heartbeat, echoes of distant songs.
If time could spool backward, reel after reel,
Would we walk old pavements, breathe in lilac dusk,
Speak aloud our quiet secrets?
In memory’s cinema, the past flickers bright:
A child waving, a lover’s smile, an open door—
Rewind, and remember. Let the heart soar.

Rewind life and remember,
How morning light tumbled across a wooden floor,
How your laughter, unburdened, danced along the walls.
The pages of days, dog-eared and inkstained,
Whispering secrets in a language we once spoke.
Remember the weightlessness of summer,
The symphony of fireflies, bedsheet forts and whispered plans.
We gather the fragments in cupped hands,
Trace them like footprints in soft sand,
And with each backward glance,
We build a bridge across time’s river,
Returning home, if only for a moment,
To find, tucked deep in memory’s attic,
The pieces of who we were, and who we might still be.

Rewind life and remember—
The gentle hush of before, the careless echo of after.
We unspool years like film in a darkened room,
Watching the colors run backward toward innocence.
In that sepia world, old shoes never pinched, and eyes
Found wonder behind every door.
What tales would we retell, what hands would we hold
If forgiving time allowed us another swing?
In dust-lit corners, our laughter still lingers,
Waiting to be recalled like a favorite song.
Memory’s gentle rewind, refusing to let go—
Each image, a lantern in the dusk,
Guiding us tenderly to days we thought
Forever gone, but never truly lost.

Rewind life and remember:
Scripted smiles behind birthday cake candles,
Midnight talks, confessions stitched into the dark.
Songs hummed in kitchens where sunlight sways,
Suitcases packed for places only the heart recalls.
Memory, a patient archivist, shapes our echoes—
In rose-tinted frames, heartbreak softens;
Forgiveness is easier with distance.
If only the world spun the other way,
If only footprints led back to precious beginnings.
Yet, by simply remembering, we rescue what matters:
Moments caught in amber, names spoken in hope—
Rewind life, not to change, but to cherish:
For every ending, the past holds a small forever
Guiding us forward, gently, by the hand.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

text.response:
Rewind life and remember
the gentle thrum of childhood laughter,
crickets singing beneath deep summer skies,
daylight lingering just a little longer.
Recall the echoes of footsteps on silent streets,
innocent promises made by the playground fence,
the warmth of small hands searching for comfort.
Let the memories tumble, grain by golden grain—
paper boats drifting on streams of sunlight,
a mother’s gentle hum, a story before sleep.
Rewind life, let nostalgia soften the heart’s edges,
and in remembering, find lost wonders again.

Rewind life and remember—the taste of rain upon your tongue,
damp earth awakening after the storm, the thrill of new beginnings.
Recall that time you danced beneath streetlights, careless, alive,
when every possibility hung dazzling above your head.
In shadowy rooms tinged with childhood’s laughter,
leaf through your soul’s old photographs, each page a soft ache.
Let memory guide you, footsteps in dew, toward who you were:
tiny hands and big dreams, promises carved in sidewalk chalk.
Rewind, and breathe in yesterday’s air,
allow those embers to glow in today’s weary fire.

Rewind life and remember
the mosaic of moments you built,
fragments glimmering like shards of sun
on the surface of a quiet pond.
Recall a first bicycle ride, trembling wheels—
the rush of wind, the certainty of small victories.
Remember whispered secrets shared under blankets,
the wide-eyed wonder at falling stars.
Trace the history etched in the lines of your palms,
braided from laughter and sorrow, hope and forgetting.
To rewind is to recognize yourself again—
in the sweet ache of what once was and what endures.

Rewind life and remember—
the way your father’s hand felt in yours,
the secret language shared by you and your childhood pet.
Recall the perfume of spring after long, cold months,
the first tentative note you played on a dusty piano.
Life’s film unspools, frame by frame: wonder, missteps, joy.
Find comfort in dust motes dancing in afternoon slants,
a book’s dog-eared page, a friend’s knowing smile.
Pause the reel on a moment that shimmers—where you laughed till it hurt,
where you fell but still rose. Remember, and rewind,
for the past is a lantern you carry, illuminating the road ahead.

Rewind life and remember
the sound of your own unguarded laugh,
the grainy warmth of old sunlight through your window.
Gather, like fallen leaves, fragments of first friends,
those endless hours woven from ordinary magic.
Let memories bloom with the scent of rain on pavement
and the hush of snow settling on empty streets.
Embrace the ache and fullness together—
the tapestry stitched from quiet regrets and loud joys.
Rewind, softly: for in remembering, we relight
the lanterns that guided us, making present
those vanished yesterdays yet aglow in our hearts.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

text.response:
I was a grovelling creature once, beneath the yawning moon,
A whisper in the willow's breath, a sorrow out of tune.
My knuckles pressed to earth's embrace, each prayer a plea for day,
Salted tears on ancient stones, hope fading into grey.
Yet even in that shadowed place, a tiny flame was spun—
A trembling wish upon the wind, a birth not yet begun.
Now I wear this sky-borne skin, my feet adrift from clay;
Once grovelling and gravity-worn, but destined to find my way.

---

I was a grovelling creature once, clawed and bent and low,
Crawling through memory's brambles, aching for seeds to sow.
I licked the roots of shame and drank dew from sorrow’s vine,
Built a home beneath the surface—a world of mine, not thine.
But the sun, insistent, beckoned, painting cracks across my shell;
I sloughed the mire, shed the dark, from hollow up I fell.
Now, upright in the daylight, heart crystalline and clear—
I was a grovelling creature once, but see me standing here.

---

I was a grovelling creature once, my fingers rimed with dust,
Stooped under silence and hunger, draped in a sheath of rust.
Rummaging for forgotten kindness in heaps of withered years,
I ate the rind of yesterday, fermented in my fears.
But hope is stubborn lightning—striking stone until it glows,
I kindled fire in my marrow where only shadow grows.
Now, the wind calls out my spirit, my limbs uncoil and rise;
A creature once of begging—now a bold new shape defies.

---

I was a grovelling creature once, hands gnarled by regret,
Gazing skyward through a forest of ambitions unmet.
My back bent lower, tracing wounds in the mud,
The rhythm of defeat throbbing hot in my blood.
But a seed found the hollow where my faith used to grow
And split open my darkness with a whisper of "go."
I’ll tell it to the sparrow, to the dawn’s first glance,
How I rose from the grovelling and dared myself to dance.

---

I was a grovelling creature once, hunched beneath my load,
Digging for comfort in a silence hardly owed.
The world pressed its weight, heavy hands of bronze and shame,
My voice a muffled plea, too quiet to claim a name.
Yet somewhere soft, defiance stirred from embers barely seen,
A current in my bloodstream urgent, restless, keen.
Now shoulders square and eyes alight with purposes begun—
I was a grovelling creature once—see what I’ve become.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

text.response:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Face pressed low to earthen crust,
Crawling through the sodden leaves,
Eyes cast downward, dreams unreleased.

The moon, far and unattainable,
Lit my trembling, shadowed course;
Fear and hunger drove my hours,
Tail coiled tight with secret remorse.

Yet, a seed of hope was sown—
A whisper in the ancient loam—
From which I learned to rise, to see,
No longer slave to misery.

Now, on trembling legs I stand,
Face uplifted, open hand.
From beast to being, I have grown—
Broken chains, spirit sewn.

I was a grovelling creature once,
My hands scraped raw by stone and root;
The world, immense, indifferent, dense—
My heart a frightened, trembling lute.

In earth's dark veins, I carved my song,
Timid notes, timid dreams, unsure.
But hunger steels the spirit strong—
And with each pang, I rose more pure.

Now, dawn distills my body’s clay,
A silhouette against the sun,
The grit of suffering swept away,
A new embrace, a life begun.

No longer at the mercy, small,
Of dark and dust and muted needs,
I rise, I walk; I will not crawl—
For hope is what the struggle breeds.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Reduced to whispers, bones, and dust;
A supplicant beneath the stars,
With hunger clutching at my trust.

Mud on my knees, dew in my mouth,
Aching for warmth, craving release.
Yet, slowly, dawn peeled back the night—
A gentle teaching, hope's increase.

Roots once tangled round my skin
Became the ladders I could climb;
In learning depth, I learned to swim—
To rise, transformed by patient time.

No longer grovelling in the gloom,
I stretch like sunlight, wild and free.
From humble shadow, I resume
My shape, my breath, my destiny.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Blind in the hollow of the ground,
Haunted by the echoing silence,
Tethered to unspoken bounds.

My form curled, small and silent,
Invisible beneath the weight—
The world above, a distant riot,
While hope slipped quietly from the gate.

But rain remembered paths to me,
And thunder beckoned limbs to rise.
With trembling thought, I knelt and pled
To taste the color in the skies.

Now light aches through memory’s door,
And memory aches to become light.
I was a grovelling creature once,
But now—how gloriously I write!

I was a grovelling creature once,
Mired in self-made valleys deep,
Fingers clutching handfuls of mud,
Too timid yet for dreams to leap.

Eyes fixed on roots and crawling things,
Unwilling to believe in flight.
I counted every sting and scar,
A ledger of perpetual night.

But hunger for the sun survives
Even in the bleakest hollow.
So, inch by inch, I taught my bones
The daring posture of tomorrow.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But stories flickered in my mind,
And now I stand and speak and sing—
Leaving old shadows far behind.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

text.response:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Bent low within the sullen dust,
Beneath the boots of fate, I shook—
A whisper in the world, a hush.
With hunger gnawing at my dreams,
My body curled, my spirit thin,
I watched the stars through slotted beams,
Unsure where hope might dare begin.
But slow as ivy climbs the stones,
A longing tangled in my chest—
A promise: "Rise, and claim your bones."
I listened, faltered, did my best.
Now light comes softly through the gloom;
I stand—not conquered, but in bloom.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Shackled to shadows, frail with doubt,
My fingertips traced the crust of longing—
Afraid to speak, afraid to shout.
The earth pressed cold against my lips,
Every breath a borrowed plea,
Yet deep inside, the fire flicked,
A secret call to set me free.
From whispered roots, my spirit grew,
Telling tales beneath the weight.
Through mud and night, my courage flew—
Wings uncurled to greet the fate.
Now I stride with head held high,
Leaving old fears where they lie.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Slinking through the mud, unseen,
My heart a stone caged in my chest,
My eyes dim upon the green.
I begged the earth for morsels bare,
Hiding from the zealous light—
The world above refused to care,
So I slumbered with the night.
Yet something stirred—a trembling leaf—
A scarlet worm, a sudden rain,
Awoke in me the faint belief
That struggle would not end in vain.
Now up I stretch, reborn and tall,
From crawling thing to standing soul, through all.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Hands clinging to the clay,
A lifeless sun and silent stones
Marked the boundaries of my day.
I learned to bow, to scurry, hide,
To fear the coming storm,
Yet, craving more than mere survival,
I ached to walk transformed.
With trembling spine, I straightened up,
Dared glimpse the cloudless sky,
Forgot the taste of dust I'd known—
Learned, at last, to fly.
Now my shadow follows lightly,
A memory in the dew;
For I was a grovelling creature once—
But oh, how far I grew.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Bound to the earth by shame,
I kissed the hem of passing boots
And learned to bear the blame.
My voice, a moth within my throat,
My courage tucked away,
Each step a plea the world miswrote—
Just survival for the day.
But in the slow uncoiling dark
A stubborn ember flared—
A spark of longing, wild and stark,
A dream that I still dared.
Today I stand upon the years
That tried to keep me small;
No longer grovelling, I am whole,
Unbowed, I greet them all.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

text.response:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Back hunched to dusty earth below;
Fingernails crusted with longing,
Eyes cowering from stars aglow.
Shadows my only companions,
Fear nestling deep in my bones;
But year by year, mote by mote,
Strength gathered, and courage atones.
Now I stride through fields unchained,
Head lifted, singing to the dawn;
No longer shackled by yesterday,
But blossomed anew, fear withdrawn.
Where I once scraped against the ground
I now dance, no chains to bear—
A creature reborn, forging onward,
In the wild, emancipated air.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Skittering in the muck of doubt,
Buried in shadows, heavy and dense,
Learning the taste of shutout.
Each day a crawl, each breath a plea,
My voice merely a whisper’s runt;
The world above too high to see,
Pride shriveled by affront.
But time, the sculptor, shaped my bones,
Drew solace from the stone and mud:
I rose, as dawn dispelled my groans,
And let my spirit flood.
Now standing tall, I face the sun;
No longer do I merely survive—
Above the soil, my race begun,
I wear the light and thrive.

I was a grovelling creature once—
The ruins of hope in my wake,
A shamble, a shadow, a silent response
To the cracks in the heart that break.
I clung to the ankles of passing dreams,
Letting miracles pass me by,
Afraid of the song of rippling streams,
Resigned to the earth and the sky.
But seasons whispered, soft and low,
That wings lay beneath the grime,
And so I stretched, and so I rose,
Shedding the mold of time.
Now echoes those earthbound days,
A lesson on how we begin:
For I learned to meet the sun’s gaze—
And wake the fire within.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Beneath the boots of thunderous days.
My voice was woven among the dust,
My dreams drowned in hollow haze.
Humbled by hunger, ruled by thirst,
I sought comfort in pebbled ground;
Fears and failures quenching my firsts,
Where hope was hardly found.
Yet from mud and mournful measure,
A seed of resolve took root;
Determination, exquisite treasure,
Rose from the beaten brute.
Now I stand, no longer small,
Eyes reflecting rising suns;
Once I grovelled, now I call—
Free, unfinished, and begun.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Spine curled to fit the gloom’s embrace;
A wordless plea in every glance,
A ghost in my own shrinking space.
The world seemed vast, and I so slight—
A flicker smothered by the night.
Yet even as I crouched in fear,
A distant voice called: up, draw near.
With trembling hands and wary heart,
I reached for light, an awkward start.
Each inch I claimed, a silent roar—
Refusing darkness evermore.
Now standing tall, I claim my name,
No longer diminished by shame;
A soul once fallen, sprawled and thin,
Now rises up—alive within.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

text.response:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Curled beneath the weight of want and woe,
My palms pressed to the hungry earth,
Dreams muffled by the soil below.
But seasons shift, and roots recall
How sunlight shakes the sullen dust;
From humble dark, a hope unfurls—a call,
Twisting, trembling, but rising, as it must.
Now I stand, a bruised yet brighter being,
With footprints soft on yesterday’s remorse,
And every trembling step is worth the seeing
For how it scribed new courage in my course.
No longer grovelling, but gently bold,
Carried by the strength that once consoled.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Crawling along the borderlands of fear,
My heart a stone, my voice withheld,
Eyes fixed downward, unclear.
In darkness I borrowed my shape,
Miens fashioned from shame’s embrace,
Yet deep within, a restless ache,
Longed to lift my gaze, to race.
With time’s slow turning, I awoke,
The world above no longer out of reach.
Rising, trembling, I shed my yoke—
Learning hope is what I teach.
No longer hunched against the light,
I claim my sky. I claim my right.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Fumbling in the shadow’s keep,
A whisper lost beneath the stones,
A hope too timid, fast asleep.
My voice was moss on ancient walls,
My dreams a hush of distant drum.
Yet hunger grew with each moon’s rise;
A silent storm was soon to come.
At dawn, I cracked my carapace,
Let light invade with liquid fire.
Unfurled, I found my standing place—
Crawled no more, but scaled higher.
For the earth remembers every trace,
Of wings that lift, and feet that chase.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Burrowed close to regret’s core,
Clinging to the smallest crumbs
Of grace scattered on a stone-cold floor.
Beneath the towering feet of fate,
I measured time by hollow ache—
But hope, insistent, would not abate,
And from its whisper, I did wake.
I rose, not in a sweep or leap,
But with the stubborn, patient art
Of one who learns, knee-deep
In darkness, to upturn the heart.
Now, through upright eyes I see:
A world I helped unbury me.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Bound to mud and marrow’s lore,
Underneath ambition’s boots,
Starving to be something more.
The sun mocked, high and bright,
While I pressed my forehead to the ground,
Yet seeds cracked in my silent night,
Roots twisting, wild and profound.
From lowliness, I limbed and climbed,
Shedding skin made of despair,
Transfiguring defeat to rhyme—
New air, new heights, new dare.
To tell this story is my want:
I was a grovelling creature once.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

text.response:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Crawling through the shadow and the dawn,
My knees were bruised by unseen stones,
Voice buried, spirit withdrawn.
Chains of regret clinked on the floor,
Hollow echoes of distant days,
Yet in the dust, a glimmer grew—
A stubborn spark that set ablaze.
Now standing tall where I once knelt,
I shed the mud, the fear, the pain;
A creature forged and redefined,
Reborn and roaring in the rain.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Hands caked in longing, eyes lowered to the dew,
Afraid to claim a place beneath suns,
Content with crumbs hope only barely threw.
Yet time’s old wheel turned ever slow,
And roots cracked stone beneath my nails,
From prostrate earth I learned to grow,
To stretch, to fight—where will prevails.
So now I stride with upright spine,
My silhouette etched sharp with dawn,
Not mourning what was once decline,
But singing fierce, my burdens gone.

I was a grovelling creature once,
A trembling shape resigned to dust,
Chasing shadows with silent screams,
Trading golden hours for rust.
Yet moonlit mercy found me there,
Wrapped gentle fingers round my scars,
And taught me lessons soft and rare
Of strength unseen by passing stars.
Now, shoulders squared and head held high,
I praise the ground which let me rise,
A testament to healing sky—
From grovelling roots, I claim my prize.

I was a grovelling creature once,
A quarry for the world’s disdain,
My heart a bird with battered wings,
My hopes dissolving in the rain.
But down among the worms and stone,
I learned to listen to the earth:
Its subtle hum, its veins of bone,
Whispered the secret of rebirth.
Now I emerge, uncurled, unbound,
Shaking the loam from every thought,
Reborn in sun and solid ground,
A truth and dignity self-taught.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Nestled in darkness, heedless, small;
My dreams mere crumbs swept from the feast,
My name called seldom, if at all.
But hunger grew a wild, bright root,
And longing pried my fingers free;
From knotted soil, hope pressed its shoot,
And coaxed the upright form of me.
Now, memory bows to rising pride;
The crawl, the bruise, the burn, the shame
Are ink where my new story’s tried—
I write upon them, claim my name.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

text.response:
People are happy, crayons bright inside their hands,
Scattered laughter spinning like dust across the sands.
A Sunday painted golden, petals on the air—
They find their joy in heat and haste, as though they haven’t a care.
Sidewalks echo memories, chalked in pastel lines,
Every smile a sunrise, gentle by design.
Candied hopes and wishes tucked behind their eyes—
Yes, people are happy, and I watch, amazed, nearby.

In these simple moments, I learn how to be—
How effortless the sunshine feels, how boundless feels the sea.
To join the dance, I close my eyes, and let the world unfold.
People are happy, and their happiness is bold.

People are happy, sunlight in their stride,
Carrying dreams like feathers on the endless countryside.
Their laughter is a ribbon, trailing through the air,
Binding hearts together with nothing but gentle care.

People are happy, faces turned to the sky—
Each moment a firework, no need to wonder why.
They gather in quiet corners and open city squares,
Sharing silent comfort, a fellowship that repairs.

People are happy, and happiness flows free—
Simple, soft, and honest as the ever-growing tree.
Let me wander in their chorus, find solace in their song; 
People are happy here, and in happiness, I belong.

People are happy, weaving threads of golden light,
Their laughter spills across the pavement, rising into night.
Coffee cups and morning walks, shared in quiet peace,
Worries gently disappearing, souls allowed release.

People are happy, every smile a spark,
Lighting up the city’s ever-deepening dark.
Hands entwined in fleeting touch, stories softly told—
Bridges built on kindness, on faith, both young and old.

Beneath the endless sky, joy is found in little things—
A silent look, a fleeting word, the hush of birds with wings.
People are happy, though sometimes shadows fall—
They find each other, hopeful, and rise above it all.

People are happy, sunlight stitched in their veins;
They toss their worries to the wind, let laughter cleanse old stains.
Children chalk rainbows on cobblestone streets,
Adults pause and marvel at new friends they meet.

Happiness dances in the clink of cups,
In late-night talks, and gentle set-ups.
It shimmers on rivers, glows in dawn’s haze,
Flickering softly in everyday praise.

People are happy, as the seasons spin,
Finding secret treasures hidden deep within.
And while storms may gather along the horizon’s rim,
They bask, for this bright hour, in gladness to the brim.

People are happy, and their joy is contagious—
Sprinkled like confetti, reckless and courageous.
They paint their days in watercolor hues,
Find beauty in storms, and pleasure in news.

Hearts beat in rhythm, strangers share a grin—
Even busy city streets feel welcoming again.
Contentment isn’t perfect, and sorrows still appear,
But people are happy, and hope draws near.

Maybe it’s the laughter, the warmth in embrace,
Or fleeting moments of peace that time can’t replace.
People are happy, and for a moment, so am I—
Cocooned in their gladness, beneath the boundless sky.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

text.response:
People are happy in the blushing dawn,
Their laughter spilled across the waking street.
Morning’s gold brushes windows forlorn,
Warming cold hands and heartbeat.
They dance with coffee, sip on the sun,
Chasing possibilities yet begun.
Simple rituals, the gentle touch of day—
People are happy in their own quiet way.

And when the evening slips in soft and slow,
Happiness lingers in twilight’s glow.
Shared stories, gentle smiles at rest—
People are happy, feeling blessed.

People are happy underneath the willow trees,
Their voices flutter on the summer air with ease.
Sunshine paints their faces, warm as memory’s dream,
Moments sweet as honey, bright as sunbeam.

Their laughter weaves through clover, anchored in the grass,
Safely rooted in the now, content to let joy pass.
They gather in circles, wide as open arms,
People are happy, wrapped in everyday charms.

Night falls softly, yet the happiness remains—
Echoes of laughter in the soft, dusky rain.

People are happy where the small things bloom:
In sidewalk cracks, in the scent of rain, in kitchen’s gentle gloom.
In quiet grocery aisles, in the warmth of knotted hands,
Their hearts leap lightly over mundane lands.

They find joy in fragments—broken but bright,
In mismatched socks, late-night talks, a streetlamp’s light.
People are happy, not always in great ways,
But in patchwork pieces embroidered through their days.

People are happy not just in the sunlight,
But beneath umbrellas, dripping in the rain.
Their smiles form puddles of reflected sky,
Scooping up dreams with hands unchained.

Children chase laughter, parents chase time,
Neighbors share stories, softly entwined.
People are happy, even when shadows play,
Finding small wonders folded in each day.

Happiness: a mosaic of laughter and tears—
A song that grows brighter through passing years.

People are happy, or so they say—
With painted faces and pockets full of day.
But happiness flickers like lamp-lit halls,
It hides in the corners and climbs up the walls.

Sometimes it’s whispered, small as a sigh,
Or dances in sunlight, passes you by.
Yet for all their searching, all their schemes,
People are happy, tucked inside dreams.
In the hush of hope and the light of chance,
They find happiness—if just at a glance.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

text.response:
People are happy, or so it seems,
Walking brightly through sun-dappled streets.
Their laughter echoes in morning dreams,
A river of joy that softly repeats.
Yet behind every grin, there’s a flicker, a shade—
A memory of struggle, silent and brave.
But hope threads the day with handwoven gold,
And in each gentle greeting, a new tale’s retold.
People are happy—perhaps not always whole,
But piecing together joy in a tapestry of soul.

People are happy, painted in dawn's embrace,
Chasing rays of sunlight as they illuminate each face.
With pockets full of laughter and hands unclenched and free,
They spill their stories gently, like leaves shaken from a tree.
Yet sometimes silence weaves between each spoken word,
A quiet, gentle longing that rarely can be heard.
Still, in the gentle morning, amidst conversation's flow,
People are happy, building warmth from what they know.

People are happy, like songbirds at play,
Filling the air with notes of today.
Their hearts like open windows to summertime air,
They trade simple kindnesses, thoughtful and rare.
Yet happiness dances, a quiver, a gleam,
Elusive and fleeting as a midsummer dream.
But in the quiet corners, in laughter and cheer,
People are happy, if only right here.

People are happy, on benches of green,
Savoring sunlight and slow, silent scenes.
Their eyes meet in kindness, their burdens made light,
By the small, passing smiles, warm in the night.
Through markets and alleys and parks paved with stone,
People are happy, together yet alone.
Happiness fragile as a petal in spring,
Lifted and flown on invisible wings.

People are happy, or so they claim,
A mosaic of faces, no two quite the same.
Some cradle their joy like a candle's small flame,
Others wear happiness more like a name.
In cafes and crosswalks, in gardens at noon,
Their laughter is stitched by the hand of the moon.
But look a bit closer, past surface and skin—
People are happy, and longing within.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

text.response:
People are happy when the sun unfolds
Its drowsy light on cobblestone streets,
Children chasing daisies in parks,
Old friends laughing at corner cafes,
And in windows open to summer's breath,
Curtains ripple in contented rhythm.
People are happy not for loud triumphs,
But in whispered joy of everyday scenes—
a dog’s wagging tail, a letter from afar,
a favorite song humming on the radio.
They gather these moments like wildflowers,
Petals tucked into pockets and behind ears—
treasures that bloom when the world grows cold.
People are happy, and for a while,
The earth sighs, at ease, cradling all its hopes.

People are happy in the golden hour glow,
When time seems to slow in honeyed air,
Laughter stitches clouds with invisible thread,
And wishes hang low on blossoming trees.
People are happy with hands interlaced,
Sharing the warmth of everyday dreams,
The hush between heartbeats, the light on a face,
The promise of kindness in small, vibrant streams.
People are happy, just quietly so,
Finding miracles within the routine—
The simple, the silent, the soft in between.

People are happy, the birds seem to say,
As dawn paints the rooftops in delicate grey.
Their chatter, a chorus, their wings, a parade—
Life folding softly into lemonade shade.
From windows flung wide to the street down below,
The laughter pours out in a jubilant flow.
People are happy, with sunlight in hair,
Dancing in kitchens while morning is fair.
The world, for a moment, is gentle and kind,
Unburdened by worry, by sorrow, by time.
Let’s hold it a while, this luminous day—
People are happy and hope finds its way.

People are happy, or so the story’s told,
In fragments of morning and silver-laced gold.
They gather like dew on sweet meadow grass,
Moments unnoticed as quietly they pass.
The thrum of a song in a market square,
Familiar faces in lamplight, aware—
Joy is a quilt sewn together by chance,
A spin in the rain, a clandestine dance.
People are happy in the warmth of a glance,
Crumpled old photos, kids lost in a trance.
In the hush between heartbeats, where gratitude grows,
People are happy—sometimes, and the world shows.

People are happy, with pockets of laughter
Tucked into the canvas of ordinary days.
They find it in echoes on winding staircases,
And in seasons that shimmer in complicated ways.
People are happy, with sunlight in teacups,
With stories retold by the light of the moon.
Simple songs carried by whistling wind
Remind us that joy comes and goes all too soon.
Yet for a heartbeat, it lingers—a fragment, a grace—
A smile in the mirror, a long-lost embrace.
People are happy, the world seems to sing,
And hope, like a bird, takes flight on bright wing.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

text.response:
People are happy, or so it might seem—
Smiles like stained-glass, cracked by the light,
Laughter that flutters, a half-dream,
Grasped in the day and lost by the night.
People are happy, claiming the sun,
Throwing their hearts to the wind and the sky;
Yet shadows linger when day is done,
Questions we dare not answer why.
Hope’s a gentle, shimmering haze,
A mask we wear so no one can see
That happiness comes in fleeting phase,
A moment’s gift, neither caged nor free.
But still, as petals turn to the dawn, 
We dance in a world that is never quite gone.

People are happy, so the story goes,
Dancing on sidewalks, spinning in prose.
Children in playgrounds, laughter on air,
Sunbeams on faces, windswept hair.
But happiness flickers, fragile and small,
Hiding in teacups and late-night calls.
Is it contentment, a soft gentle breeze,
Or simply a moment that drops to its knees?
Yet—see them smiling, hand in hand,
Dreams like castles on shifting sand.
People are happy, as hope unfurls,
Blooming like flowers in distant worlds.

People are happy—under painted skies,
Faces awash with unfiltered delight,
Laughter flickering in their soft eyes,
Hearts feathered and endlessly light.
Yet happiness is a glimmering art,
A song that echoes unknown,
Lingered in corners of every heart,
Carried in dances alone.
For every gladness, a memory kept,
Every smile hides a shade,
In the hush where true longing slept,
And sunlight begins to fade.
People are happy, yet none remain,
Unmarked by loss or tinged by rain.

People are happy, or that’s what they say,
Sipping warm coffee, joking away
At park bench meetings, on bright city streets,
When the world pulses and time gently repeats.
But happiness, sometimes, is borrowed and brief,
Less anchored in joy than in hopeful belief.
Still, in the hush between laughter and sighs,
Something enduring and luminous lies.
For people are happy—not always, not all;
Sometimes they stumble, sometimes they fall.
Yet in shared stories and glances that gleam,
We find threads of the joy human hearts dream.

People are happy—the world seems to sing,
In the cascade of morning, the gold light of spring.
Children with pockets of stones and of dreams,
Friends weaving laughter in sun-tangled beams.
Yet behind the music, a quieter tune—
A longing that hums in the glow of the moon.
Happiness dances, it falters, it flees,
It hides in remembrance, it rides on the breeze.
People are happy, we hope and we try,
To capture the rapture that flickers nearby.
While sorrow and wonder keep weaving between,
The spaces where happiness softly has been.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

text.response:
People are happy in sunlight’s embrace,
Carrying laughter from place to place.
Unspoken stories, woven in smiles,
Lingering gently, trailing for miles.
The warmth in their voices, the light in their eyes,
Like hopeful birds taking flight for the skies.
Each one a lantern, aglow in the gloam,
Searching for love and a sense of home.
Yes, people are happy – but deep in the seams,
Are rivers of longing and flickering dreams.
Yet onward they wander, shoulders upright,
Chasing the joy painted bright in the light.

People are happy when raindrops descend,
Dancing on sidewalks, where sorrows might bend.
Peace in the puddles, reflection so true,
Children’s sweet laughter bursting right through.
They gather like sunbeams, shimmering gold,
Stories and secrets quietly told.
People are happy, a chorus of song—
Carrying lost ones and righting the wrong.
Underneath shadows, they kindle their spark,
Igniting bright hope when the days become dark.
People are happy, despite and because,
Rooted in wonder and trust without pause.

People are happy, or so it may seem—
Bright glossy selfies and feeds full of gleam.
Yet under the screens and behind every grin,
Rooms full of silence and longing begin.
They gather in parks where the leaves gently fall,
Telling themselves they’ve conquered it all.
People are happy, hustling through days,
Binding old heartache in neat little ways.

Dreams gather in eyes, oceans of gloss,
As the world outside waits for courage to speak.
Each one a promise, a windstorm, a flight;
Small, sacred hearts growing feathers of trust.
Oh, to love so many in hush of the night—
Life trembling and wild above silence and dust.
When they leap, when they soar into amber day
I’ll count my old nest as a song, flown away.

I had eight birds hatched in one nest,
Little miracles, trembling in woven rest.
Their frail voices, a morning hymn,
Broke the hush with hopes slim.
Under a tarpaulin of dew-soaked leaves,
Eight soft chirpers, faith interweaves.
Each feathered child, a spectrum anew,
Reds, golds, and the sharpest blue.
I watched them jostle, blindly brave—
Learning the art of want and crave.
The world a forest of unknown sighs,
Marked only by their mother’s cries.
Yet short is the span to first flight’s test,
I sit, counting blessings—eight in a nest.
Soon air will cradle their beating breast,
And I’ll remember: I had eight birds at rest.

I had eight birds hatched in one nest;
A fragile cacophony of beaks and wings,
Chaos and comfort, all in jest,
A melody the ceaseless morning brings.
Feathers tousled like wishes half said,
Soft echoes of sunlight, longing for sky—
Every bright quiver, a story half read,
A wish to leap, to fall, to fly.
Crowded with dreams, a living poem spun,
Mirrored in eyes that have only just opened.
I marvel at hope, at the bright, unbroken,
Promise of eight in the arms of one.
And when the nest empties, when silence creeps near,
I’ll cherish the memory of every soft cheep I hear.

I had eight birds hatched in one nest,
A fluttering crown in the willow’s breast.
Each chick with a heart like a trembling jewel,
Linked by a thread to the mother’s rule.
Their days newborn and eyes like dew,
Unfurling feathers in halcyon blue.
They thundered with hunger, cheeped at the dawn,
Wings that would carry their legacies on.
From tangled straw their destinies grew;
Some stayed near, while others flew
To skies unknown on the breath of the breeze—
Yet always returned with the hush of the trees.
I had eight birds, a story confessed,
Of love and of longing within one nest.

I had eight birds hatched in one nest,
Air filled with hunger and gold-flecked song.
They balanced, delicate—fortunes guessed
By the tilt of dawn, where shadows belong.
Little strangers, born as kin,
Jostling for warmth on a cotton spun bed.
Together they chirped their futures in,
Unaware of the vast blue overhead.
A nest too small for dreams so grand;
Soon feathers ruffled and wings unfurled.
Off to conquer an untamed land,
Eight stories scattered into the world.
Silence settles where feathers pressed,
But my heart remembers—eight in one nest.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I had eight birds hatched in one nest,'

text.response:

I had eight birds hatched in one nest,

I had eight birds hatched in one nest,

Days unfurled like sun-warmed wings,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

text.response:
It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Soft silence poured in layers of white—
Fields erased, boundaries lost, a clover
Of hush settled beneath starless night.
Children woke to windows blurred,
Dreams drifting through muffled light,
And rooftops carried stories unheard,
Tales cocooned in the weightless bright.
Winter paused with breathless wonder,
The globe cocooned in frosty cover—
All fears dissolved as warmth slipped under:
It snowed and snowed, the whole world over.

In this quilt of cold, we draw together,
Finding hope in the hush of weather.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A breathless hush beneath the sky's white shroud.
Crossing fields and city streets, silence grew bolder,
And each sharp edge succumbed, quiet and proud.

Beneath the drifts, old footprints faded,
While tall trees bowed with powdered grace,
Dreams of sunlit pastures now evaded—
A beautiful, crystalline embrace.

Borders lost to winter's weaving,
Time stood still, hopes believing—
That after all the snow's endeavor,
Hearts would thaw, the world together.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Blanketing earth in a ghostly white,
Mountains, deserts, swamps, and clover—
All vanished beneath the hush of night.

Even oceans ceased their rolling,
Stilled by flakes beyond all measure,
As if the sky was softly tolling
A gentle pause, a hidden treasure.

In every corner, silence growing,
Beneath the spell of this white cover.
Nothing moving, nothing knowing—
It snowed and snowed, the whole world over.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over;
No city glowed, no village shivered.
Peace fell with each silent drover,
Grace upon rooftops quietly delivered.

The world forgets its hurried ticking
When night bestows such gentle blight;
In drifting veils, hope comes sticking—
Reminders spun from pale delight.

From frozen steppes to starlit pole,
One breath crosses every border;
Under endless white patrol,
It snowed and snowed, the whole world over.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Blankets falling on every land—
Palms froze in equator's cover,
Sahara dressed in icy sand.

No border checked the swirling feather,
It drifted past both friend and foe;
Unwritten truce in brumal weather,
Hope kindled in the cold's faint glow.

In snowfall, differences faded,
Just quiet awe to pass around.
Beneath white veils serenely braided,
The world found peace on hallowed ground.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

text.response:
It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Blanketing mountains, field, and clover.
Silver quiet draped each roof and road,
Time's ticking pulse lulled and slowed.
From every continent, the flakes conspired
To hush the traffic, soothe the tired.
In tiny flakes, the planet found
A gentle peace upon the ground,

Closed weary eyes and stilled their cries.
It snowed and snowed, no place forgot—
Winter's kiss, the world begot.

A single hush across the lands,
Soft white comfort in open hands,
It snowed and snowed, the world made new—
A frosted silence, pure and true.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
From desert dunes to fields of clover.
Skies whispered flakes in foreign tongues,
Upon the old and the very young.

the eiffel tower shivered in lace,
thick drifts buried the marketplace.
Antarctica met Sahara's frost,
Borders blurred and boundaries lost.

In Mumbai, Tokyo, Rio, Rome,
Every street became a home,
Blanketed under a pallid dome—
The world, united, stood alone.

It snowed and snowed, day turned to night;
All colors faded, lost in white.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Transforming cities, harbor, and heather.
Frozen breath on window glass,
Erased each sorrow, let kindness amass.

Children danced inside the storm,
Finding delight in joy reborn.
Chimneys sent signals into the gloom,
Warmth glowing within each room.

In silence fell the endless flakes,
Each a secret, each new shape.
No gem nor coin could weigh so much,
As these white messengers of touch.

It snowed and snowed, a fresh domain:
A world united by gentle rain.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Erasing all color, lover from lover.
Roads disappeared, paths were gone,
A white silence pressed on and on.

In Moscow, winds carried diamond dust;
In New York, the city’s engines hushed.
Across steppes and seas, valleys, plains,
The hush of snow replaced the rains.

Under the drift, a tired world slept,
Secrets in snowdrifts quietly kept.
It snowed and snowed, unending, deep:
Beneath, the seeds of springtime sleep.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Turning forests into fields of clover.
Vast oceans stilled by silent white,
Mountains drawn in soft twilight.

People peered through frosted glass,
Watching time and winter pass.
Each snowflake a fleeting letter
Spelling peace, making things better.

Statues dressed in sparkling shrouds,
Treetops vanished in drifting clouds.
It snowed and snowed, remaking earth,
A million tiny flakes of worth.

Beneath the weightless, muffled night,
Dreams fell gentle, soft, and bright.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

text.response:

From desert town to frozen pole,

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,

Statues cloaked in white attire,
Quiet chimneys breathing fire,
Rivers slowed by silver threads,
Scarves drawn tight around our heads.

Ice on fenceposts, frost on glass,

In every hearth, stories unfurl,
Of gentle flakes that joined the world.

It snowed and snowed, no end in sight,
A gentle shroud, a gift of light.
Upon the globe, a gentle pause—
Snow reminding what love does.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
From mountain peaks to forest cover,

It snowed on towers, domes, and steeples,
Silent streets and bustling peoples,

Wrapped the earth in wordless hush.

No bells rang, no trumpets sounded—
Just feathered flakes that softly bounded.
In every heart, a yearning grew,
For peace, for warmth, for something true.

It snowed and snowed as time stood still,
Binding us in winter’s will,
Until, beneath that weightless white,
The world remembered how to unite.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Swaddling lands in silvered clover,
Spilling secrets through the air,
Folding chaos in winter’s care.

It snowed on playgrounds long forgotten,
On memories sweet and memories rotten,
Softened edges, blurred the known,
Shaped new forms in frost and bone.

The air was thick with silent song,
As hours drifted white and long,
A parliament of clouds convened
To grant the weary world a dream.

It snowed and snowed, forever new,
The globe remade in icy dew.
Mankind, beneath that vast embrace,
Could only marvel at such grace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

text.response:
Just a few dwindling pools remain—
Shallow mirrors of a vanished rain.
Rimmed with pebbles dry and cracked,
Hope and memory both pulled back.
Sky reflected, silver thin,
Ghostly ripples soft within.
Cattails bow where water lies—
Silent, shrinking, under sighs.
Footprints pattern muddy shores,
Stories fading, nothing more.
Yet in these pools, dreams retain
A world reborn from thirst and pain.

Beneath the surface, life persists—
A froglet blinks, a beetle twists.
Though time may steal and drought may reign,
Just a few dwindling pools remain.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Tracing stories where rivers once roared,
Their liquid eyes stare up at the sky,
Whispering secrets of that which was poured.
Dragonflies hover on trembling glass,
Searching for memory, echo and sound.
Reeds sway gently, guarding the past,
Clutching the borders of hollow ground.

Sun scorches hope, yet dusk softly weeps,
And moonlight nurses with delicate dreams.
The world contracts, yet promise keeps—
Life finds a foothold, or so it seems.
For even as dryness claims the domain,
A shimmer endures in each dwindling pool—
A story of loss, resilient and cool.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
In the hollowed bowl of the glen,
Where laughter and water once ran free,
Now shadows cling to muddy men.

Dragonflies skip on battered glass,
Each ripple a memory lost or won;
The frogs croak hymns for vanished depth,
A requiem for days spent under sun.

A crust of salt frames fragile lives,
Sand drifting over broken shells.
Above, the sky, immense and dry,
Dreams of storms and distant wells.

Yet, stubborn roots clutch the silt,
And petals bloom against the grain,
For hope, like water, can distill
From just a few dwindling pools that remain.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Dappled in light of the setting sun,
Mirrors to a memory—months of rain—
Now fractured, fleeting, undone.

At banks where children once waded deep,
Empty cups of earth thirst for days
When shoals of color flickered and leaped,
Dancing along the water’s ancient ways.

Crickets hush their summer song,
Their chorus faded on silt-stained air.
Yet, within these pools, not all is gone—
Life’s gentle persistence glimmers there.

A silent promise in every drop,
Though rivers have vanished and fields are plain:
Tomorrow may come, the clouds may break—
For hope lingers where dwindling pools remain.

Just a few dwindling pools remain—
Quiet, glimmering sighs upon the plain.
Once, laughter echoed over brimming banks,
Now dust and memory fill the empty tanks.

Herons stalk among the ghostly reeds,
Tracing the silence in broken seeds.
A child’s bare feet, etching circles of mud,
Chasing the shimmer left by the flood.

Distant thunder a hollow dream,
Clouds drift indifferent to wishes or schemes.
Still, in each glint of receding blue,
A stubborn hope clings, fierce and true.

Though most have departed, faith remains here,
Waiting with frogs for the rain to appear.
A hush, a prayer beneath the curtain of sky—
Where dwindling pools refuse to die.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

text.response:
When I am happy, the world grows light—
Colors shining, gentle, bright.
A simple song hums on the breeze,
Carrying laughter past the trees.
My worries curl and drift away,
Like morning fog chased by the day.
The clock ticks soft in perfect time—
A rhythm matched to joy’s sweet rhyme.
Even the silence sings along,
A silent echo of a song.
The smallest things become profound:
A friendly smile, the birds around,
Each moment glows, alive and true—
The world itself feels born anew.
So let my happiness unfold,
A story bright and yet untold,
For when I am happy, all I see
Is beauty—hope, possibility.

When I am happy, light pours from my chest,
Filling deep corners where shadows once nested.
Clouds part, revealing the blue endless,
And even old scars become gently caressed.
I walk with a buoyant, unstoppable stride,
Rain puddles sparkle, I dance through the tide.
 Laughter spills over, unbidden, sincere,
Every face I encounter feels warmer, less near
To the sorrows and worries that once weighed me down—
Instead, all I carry’s a jubilant crown.
When I am happy, I am entirely free,
Wings sprout from hopes at the heart of me.
No map or compass can chart this terrain;
It wells up within—unscripted, unfeigned.

When I am happy, the sunlight does sing,
And the morning dew glitters with secrets it brings.
My footsteps grow lighter, a dance on the air,
Each moment revealing a world bright and rare.
Petals unfold, unafraid of their bloom,
Chasing away every shadow and gloom.
The laughter of sparrows becomes my refrain,
As joy rushes in like a summer-soft rain.
When I am happy, time slows down its chase,
And every small thing finds its sweet, perfect place.
A gentle reminder that right here, right now,
Happiness lingers—it teaches me how.

When I am happy, the rain turns to gold,
And silent wishes dare to be told.
I walk among echoed laughter, sweet and low,
With stars in my pockets and time moving slow.
The air is fresher, saturated with light,
Everything ordinary suddenly bright.
Lost in the wonder of moments so new,
I paint the world in a brighter hue.
Worries dissolve in the warmth at my core—
Each heartbeat promising something more.
When joy takes root and blossoms inside,
Every shadow has nowhere to hide.

When I am happy, the mountains bow low,
Inviting my spirit to rise and to go.
A breeze threads through hair, fingers crossed with the sky,
Suddenly gravity, gentle, barely a tie.
I taste the wild in ripe orchard air,
Drink in the laughter woven everywhere.
Small miracles—sunbeams on glass, a bee’s soft hover—
Declare themselves boldly, one after another.
In these moments, whole worlds bloom unseen,
Rich with the colors of all that might mean.
When I am happy, the universe sighs—
Grateful I’m here, alive, open-eyed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

Before me stands—I see: it’s me.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'
