Crumpled tissues bloom in silent drifts,
Memory softened by menthol dreams.
Outside, the songbirds carry on, indifferent,
While inside, I nestle deeper within myself,
Listening to the ache in my bones, the hush in my heart,
Finding unexpected peace in this quiet unwellness,
A moment to pause amid the wild, spinning rush.
Now, when I have a cold, I remember to rest,
And the world waits—for me, just this once.

Now when I have a cold,
I watch the rain trace trembling lines
across the window pane. The ordinary blurs:
soap bubbles in my tea, distant laughter outside,
the hollow tap of slippers on tile. Wrapped in blankets,
I become an island afloat, drifting between dreams
and waking. Each breath thick with memory, each exhale
an invitation to slow down. Taste lingers, sharp and strange,
nostalgia for crisp air and health sharp as spring.
The clock’s hands slip by kindly, unhurried,
holding space for recovery. The world’s demands retreat;
even the dishes, for now, forgive my neglect.
It is here, in the cocoon of illness, that gratitude grows—
a quiet solace: Now, when I have a cold, I am content
to simply be, and perhaps, to become well again.

Now when I have a cold,
I become an old house in winter—
walls whispering, wood beams creaking beneath the weight
of blankets stacked like snowdrifts. My breath is clouded glass,
dew-beaded and slow, tracing every cough through empty halls.
I sip honey tea, a golden drop of sun melting through the gloom,
and feel the hush that illness brings—
a gentle slowing, a retreat to stillness.
Books nestle beside me, stories undone—
I drift in and out, dreaming of warmth,
of spring gardens, of laughter ringing bright.
But until then, I am quiet, preserved in softest gray—
now, when I have a cold,
a hush—and nothing more—becomes my song.

Now when I have a cold,
the world softens. My speech blurs,
as though words themselves are drowsy.
The usual hum of traffic and chatter is distant,
dulled by the cotton in my head.
I move through a haze of mint and honey,
clutching steaming cups, grasping solace in warmth.
The day moves slowly—pages turn,
a mug is refilled, the dog curls in sympathy at my feet.
Outside, rain patters and wind frets, but here there’s only
the hush of my own being—a pause, a waiting,
an uneasy grace born of fever’s cocoon.
Now, when I have a cold, I notice:
the kind crinkle of blankets, the taste of solitude,
the quiet gift of stopping, just for now.

Now when I have a cold,
I remember childhood—soft voices and cool hands,
warm broth brought on a tray by someone who loved me.
Blankets piled high, curtains drawn against harsh afternoon light,
cartoons blurring between heavy eyelids. Now, alone,
I search for those comforts in the hum of a kettle,
the glow of screens, my own voice gentle inside my head.
Illness returns me to smallness, unfamiliar gentleness:
the world outside big, bright, and unreachable while I drift
in and out of fevered dreams. Each sneeze weighs heavy,
reminding me to slow down, to savor even this—
a chance to care for myself as once I was cared for.
Now, when I have a cold, I discover healing is as much memory
as medicine—restoration shaped by time and tenderness.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

text.response:
Now when I have a cold,
Time stalls like drifts of snow on lanes forgotten.
Blankets rise around my shoulders—
an attempt to seal away the chill,
But it seeps in, quiet and bold.
Mugs of tea cradle hands too tired for stories,
Steam curling like hope at my lips.
Outside, the sun still dares to rise,
but corners of the window hold condensation secrets;
I listen to rain, a soft metronome
to the scratchy rhythm of my breathing.
Each cough a punctuation mark
in the poem of waiting, waiting.
Now, when I have a cold,
The world slows to the pace of fevered dreams,
And I learn, again, the art
of resting under time’s heavy quilt.

Now when I have a cold,
The world shrinks to the radius of my bedspread,
And sunlight paints pale patterns on crumpled sheets.
Every cough echoes as a distant thunder,
And the hush of the room becomes a gentle lullaby.
I sip broth as if deciphering ancient potions,
Scan faces in the ceiling clouds,
Letting aches map the unseen trails of longing.
In this pause, memories gather,
Old laughter muffled by congestion’s fog,
Books unread stacked like patient friends.
Even the cat, wise and silent, curls near my feet,
Understanding that the body, in its battle,
Finds its way back to warmth—
Like a drowsy river meandering toward the sun.

Now when I have a cold,
I move through molasses days and honeyed nights,
Swaddled in jumpers and granny's old patchwork quilt.
Each breath, a tepid sigh, fights through clouds of vapor rub,
The world muffled as though living underwater.
Soup sloshes in chipped mugs, steam kissing my cheeks.
All ambitions shrink to the scope of dreams:
Perhaps a novel read, perhaps nothing at all.
My window is the stage for drifting raindrops,
Each one tracing lazy lines down aging glass.
Visiting thoughts flicker and fade with fever,
And I promise myself, gently, to return stronger,
To rejoin life’s clamor with clearer lungs—
But for now, wrapped in calm surrender, I listen
to the symphony of sneezes, and wait out the storm.

Now when I have a cold,
The world dims, dulled by the hazy lens
Of watery eyes and a nose that never clears.
I’m tethered by tissues and mugfuls of comfort,
Nesting in pillows, cocooned in flannel.
Flavors fade into far-off echoes; my mouth misses mint,
My ears ring with quiet, punctuated only by coughs.
Outside, birds still chatter—a reminder
That beyond the fog of illness,
spring insists on arriving. I wait,
Pause, drift between lucid thoughts and fever-fog,
Finding surprising clarity in stillness:
How rare and precious is a deep, unlabored breath,
How enduring is the patience of small comforts—
A hand on the brow, a soft voice,
a promise of wellness just beyond the window’s frame.

Now when I have a cold,
My world grows softer, edges blurred by weariness.
Even the sun seems to respect my lethargy,
Its light filtered quietly through frosted glass.
Tea cools on the nightstand, books lie unread,
And the hours unravel like loose threads on a sweater.
Each sneeze shakes out another memory
Of bustling days I’d barely noticed
When lungs were clear and fever was a stranger.
I let myself become a slow pulse under the covers,
My thoughts gentle, floaty as motes in the pale afternoon.
Now, with every sniffle, I find solace in surrender,
Trusting in warm socks and half-remembered lullabies,
Knowing the world, patient as always,
Will wait for my return to brightness.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

text.response:
Now when I have a cold,
Muffled in scarlet fleece—
I listen to the house unfold
Whispers of comfort and peace.
The kettle murmurs, windows sigh,
Rain taps a tune on the glass;
Each shiver a secret lullaby,
Soft as the hours pass.
Tea steeps in porcelain embrace,
Steam curling into the air—
With every sip, a gentle trace
Of warmth found everywhere.
Snuggled in this quiet ache,
With tissues strewn about,
I learn the gentle art to take
A breath and rest, no doubt.

Now when I have a cold,
The outside world retreats,
My thoughts grow calm and old,
And time forgets its beats.
The brightness of a fevered room,
A fortress built of wool and tea,
While shadows gently drift and loom—
My only company.
The world, for once, grows small;
Just coughs, the ticking clock,
The rise and fall, the patient thrall
Of blankets, socks, and talk
Of dreams I chase while slow and warm,
I welcome hours to unfold,
And find, within my quiet form,
A story retold anew, when I have a cold.

Now when I have a cold,
The sharpness of the world dissolves—
A hush descends, soft and uncontrolled,
And all my plans evolve.
The fever colors every thought,
Hallucinations mild and deep—
I watch the busy world I sought
Continue while I weep.
Yet in this fragile, fevered haze,
A gentleness arrives,
With every sneeze and blurry gaze
A softer self survives.
So, wrapped in tissues, tea, and care,
Beneath the blankets’ fold,
My mind drifts lighter in the air,
Now, when I have a cold.

Now when I have a cold,
I look on life through glassy eyes.
Voices drift gentle, uncontrolled,
As memory and dream surmise.
The world outside is paper-thin,
Its edges dulled and blurred,
Yet in my fevered world within,
The smallest things are heard.
The hum of heat, the teapot’s sigh,
The whisper of a page turned slow,
A sparrow flits past sullen sky—
Time trickles, sweet and low.
Pain is patient, but so am I,
Curled in blankets, caught between
A listless cough, a lullaby,
And worlds that linger, soft, unseen.

Now when I have a cold,
Sunlight slants across the room:
A golden balm, so soft and old,
Dispelling every gloom.
I crumple tissues in my fist,
And brew a cup of sage,
Each sip a gentle, fragrant tryst
That soothes this body's cage.
Outside, the world is sharp and bright,
While here, I move in haze;
Each cough a memory of night,
Each breath, a hopeful phrase.
So in my nest of wool and thought,
I drift beyond the cold,
Grateful for the rest it brought,
Stories silent, slow, and bold.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

text.response:
Now when I have a cold,
Time slows to syrup, thick and gold,
Each breath a shallow winter sigh,
Blankets nested, softly lie.
Tea steams between my languid hands,
The world makes gentle, whispered plans;
Sunlight slants in pale remains,
Outside, a drizzle hushed in panes.
Once, I hurried through the days,
But now, enclosed in fever’s haze,
I trade the rush for softer things—
The hush of sleep, the warmth it brings.
Let the world go spinning round,
For now I cherish quieter sound;
Now when I have a cold,
Rest rewrites what days can hold.

Now when I have a cold,
The world grows distant, dipped in mist;
Every flavor, every sound,
Subdued by nostrils sorely missed.
My mind drifts under blankets gray,
Craving lemon, honey, and rest,
While rain rehearses old refrains
Against the window’s chilly breast.
I daydream of a clearer head,
Of brighter streets and bustling cheer,
But lie cocooned, with mug in hand,
A tired ghost with nowhere near
A care for clocks or crowded streets—
Let deadlines drift and plans unfold.
I savor slowness, one sweet beat:
Now when I have a cold.

Now when I have a cold,
Life shrinks to fleece and ginger tea,
To tissues balled in wilting mounds,
And memories of liberty.
Outside, the sparrows gather crumbs,
But I become a drifting thought,
Wrapped in quilts, while fever plumbs
The stories I had half-forgot.
Somehow the simple seems profound—
The flavor of an orange slice,
The way a shaft of afternoon
Transforms the bedroom curtains’ lice.
Now when I have a cold,
The world grows small and slow,
I listen to my beating heart,
And let this quiet fever flow.

Now when I have a cold,
My windows frost with dreams,
Each sneeze a lonely toll,
Each cough a distant seam
That stitches up my waking hours,
While ginger tea and lemon powers
Attempt to soothe my restless bones.
The world outside now feels unknown:
A theater seen through misted glass,
Where actors hurry, jest, and pass.
For now, I nest amid the hush,
Letting daily worries rush
Past the barricades of sleep,
Where dreams ferment, and silence seeps.
Tomorrow waits; today I fold
Into the hush of having a cold.

Now when I have a cold,
I measure days by cups of tea
And notice things I never might:
The patterned shadow of a tree,
The flecks of gold in winter light.
Chores will fade and time will slow,
My thoughts parade in languid pace,
As if the world itself would know
To soften lines around my face.
I settle in with aching bones,
Press gentle palms against my skin,
And in this stillness, something grows—
A tenderness that dwells within.
A cold might pause the headlong race,
But leaves behind, when I am whole,
A quiet, unexpected grace
That lingers in a grateful soul.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

text.response:
Now when I have a cold,
The world shrinks to the inches
of my quilt, a lonely landscape
charted by coughs and sighs.
Sunlight scrawls ghostly shapes
upon my bedroom wall, turning
each droplet of breath into
clouds adrift in stale morning air.
Outside, life tumbles onward—
wind’s laughter teasing the window, 
friends’ footsteps echoing on stone—
but I float at the edge of things,
measured in spoons of broth,
in the company of tissues and books.
Dreams fever through the afternoon:
fields of daffodils, pollenless and gold.
Soon I’ll re-enter living’s dance,
but for now, my world is small,
a quiet retreat, a pause called Cold.

Now when I have a cold,
Time slows into crystal droplets—
Honey swirling in tea, steam rising gentle and bold.
Blankets nestle around my shoulders, cocooned in softness,
A fortress built against the chill of winter’s hold.
Words dissolve into whispers, phone calls become
murky echoes from far-off, vibrant lands, 
And I drift, half-awake, through fragments of dreams;
Childhood afternoons beside my grandmother’s fire,
Citrus slices glowing bright in her smile.
The world outside hurries, runny and relentless,
But here, congestion hushes ambition beneath the hush.
I rediscover sweet patience, the luxury of pause—
Outside, nothing misses me much.
Now when I have a cold,
The earth slows with me, and I savor the hush.

Now when I have a cold,
The simplest things turn miracles—
Clean, cool water soothes like a lover’s hand,
Lemon and honey swirl into golden calm.
I measure the hours by the steep of tea,
A symphony of sneezes punctuating the quiet room.
Between naps I remember, life sometimes asks us
to be small: to shrink into a comforter,
and let the world circulate beyond these walls.
Streetlights blur in fevered twilights, I dream
Of wind in branches, the salt of unbothered air.
For now I am only a bundle of aches,
Soft-edged, slow, and wondrously mortal—
Grateful for the lull, this gentle permission,
Held by the hush of having a cold.

Now when I have a cold,
The world dims and narrows to my breath,
A small, slow universe spun with menthol threads.
Night thickens at my window, and the familiar hum of distant cars
Lulls me toward uneasy sleep.
Memories float up, blurred at their corners:
Childhood nights tucked under quilts,
My mother’s cool hand on my brow, minty balm on my chest.
The taste of broth, the hush of low lamp-light,
Pages turning softly in the hush.
I am slowed, made tender by discomfort,
Reminded that vulnerability is a secret door
To gentleness, to patience I forget when well.
In these fevered days, the body becomes a prayer,
Each inhalation, a fragile hope:
That soon, health will tiptoe back—a quiet, golden guest.

Now when I have a cold,
Even silence thickens, clinging to the drape,
The room closes in, dizzy with menthol and hope.
My body creaks and aches, a clock wound slow—
I tiptoe among used tissues, a pale constellation on the floor.
Old stories on the radio drift me through the night,
Each breath precious, hard-won as the dawn.
Outside, impatience thrums beneath passing tires,
While I watch, idling, wrapped in layers, a patient observer
Of time’s slow unraveling.
In this minor exile, I learn new languages:
Of self-kindness, of incremental mending,
Of letting go control. I become softer,
A patchwork of longing and gratitude stitched into rest.
Now, with this frail cold, I join
the secret society of the slowed—the quietly resilient, resting, waiting to unfold.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

text.response:
How swiftly, slyly does the shadow creep,
A hush of years upon my gathering day;
With every heartbeat, Time begins to sweep
The golden haze of innocence away.
A subtle thief with hands both light and deft,
He steals the laughter, softens every line—
Yet in his wake, what quiet gifts are left:
A wisdom grown, a courage to be kind.
Oh, Time! Relentless, silent in pursuit,
You prune the tenderness from budding truth,
Yet plant within me courage as your fruit—
How soon you claimed the bloom of restless youth.
Still, in your passage, I shall find my prime,
And thank the thief for shaping love with time.

---

Time, the silent whisperer of change, draws near,
His footsteps muffled in the corridors of days.
He brushes past the mirror, leaving each year
A shade paler, a memory set ablaze.
Blithe youth, so fleet, whirls out of sight,
Exchanged for lines of laughter, fears subdued.
How sly this thief who works in velvet night,
To steal our reckless dreams—yet leave the truth renewed.
Where once I mourned the turn of fleeting hours,
I find now richer soil for inner flowers.
No thief, but gardener, Time’s steady hand sows
A fuller harvest from what the young self knows.

---

How soon hath Time, with feathered step and guile,
Lifted the dawn from out my eager hands.
The seasons blur, and still with secret smile
He draws the maps my aging heart expands.
Youth’s fervent pulse he covets dearly, yet
In every theft a lesson’s seed is laid;
Grief ripens sweet with memories unmet,
As hope endures the setbacks time has made.
O subtle foe, yet partner of the soul,
Whose pilfered hours teach more than loss can tell—
With every year, a greater, nobler goal;
In Time’s great theft, my truest self grows well.

---

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Slipped through the windows of my careless mind;
He steals with gentle hands, disguised as truth,
And leaves behind a wisdom hard to find.
The dreams I cradled with a child's intent
Have softened in the dusk of growing old,
Yet casting off the hopes that once were spent,
Reveals new beauty in stories yet untold.
For as he takes, Time also kindly gives:
A patience shaped by moments long ago.
We shed our youth, and find that what now lives
Is deeper love and peace we come to know.
So let Time’s larceny be sweet and mild—
For in its theft, the soul becomes beguiled.

---

How soon hath Time, on silent slippers drawn,
Stealed the sprightly vigor from my hour,
His gentle fingers plucking, one by one,
The untamed colors of my youthful bower.
Yet not in vain does he his trade pursue—
Each moment lost exchanged for vision clear;
In every wrinkle, wisdom’s virtue grew;
With every season, I hold less to fear.
The subtle thief may rob the downy years,
But leaves behind a softer, wiser heart;
He tempers joy, refines our ancient tears,
And gifts us grace for every new restart.
So let him thieve; I greet change with a smile—
For in Time’s hands, my soul learns to compile.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

text.response:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Slipped through the gates, disrobing golden days?
His gentle fingers, masked in careless truth,
Unspool the laughter, mute the children’s praise.
A mirror’s glaze reflects a stranger’s face,
While memory clings to vanished April light.
Yet in this theft, a subtler gift I trace:
New wisdom flourishes from vanished might.
Though fleeting are the flush of cheek and limb,
And quick the clock to pilfer fair delight,
Still in Time’s passage, paradox grows dim—
The loss is birth, the day redeemed by night.
So let me greet this subtle thief with grace,
For what he takes, he leaves—in heart and face.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept softly, silent, through the latticed years,
Siphoning the joy, the candor, and the truth,
Leaving only echoes and bittersweet souvenirs.
Once golden dawns now fade to woven dusk,
And echoes in the corridors of thought remain;
A shadow lingers where fragrance used to musk—
Childhood’s innocence, exchanged for silent gain.
Yet seeds of wisdom in the loam he sowed,
Blossom now, in older, richer flower,
Their roots entwined in every road I strode,
Fed by memory’s tender, gentle power.
Though youth slips by on Time’s unchecked wings,
He leaves the soul the gift of deeper things.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
With velvet tread, he pockets hope and fire.
A master burglar—quiet, deft, uncouth—
He whittles down our passionate desire.
Reflections, fleeting ghosts within the glass,
Recall the zest that danced within our bones.
Where spring once lingered, bare October grass
Now whispers softly in nostalgic tones.
But though he steals our careless, daring ways,
Time offers in their stead a fresher view:
A palette richer, toned by autumn’s haze,
A strength more braced, ambitions born anew.
So let us bless this thief with gentle hands,
For all he takes, a wider world expands.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
With gloved hands brushing tenderness aside,
He steals tomorrow’s promise, dims the truth,
While zephyrs shift and summer roses hide.
In secret chambers memories ignite:
A playground, laughter, morning in our eyes.
Yet onward flows the current to the night—
We gather dreams, then let them vaporize.
But in the hollow left, some treasures rest—
Resilience forged in patient, tempered pain.
The heart, though older, pulses with its quest,
And wonders, weathered, quietly remain.
Thus Time, sly pickpocket, pilfers years,
But forfeits all to hope that reappears.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stolen the dew from dawn’s awakening face.
He tiptoes, garbed in age, with mocking truth,
And weaves each wrinkle with appalling grace.
The bloom that sang of childhood, fierce and bright,
Now dims beneath the silver touch of days.
Yet in his shadowed art, a new delight—
Folded in wisdom’s textiles, memory plays.
He cannot rob the courage softly grown,
Or dim the light of longing in the soul.
For though he hastens flesh to wear and bone,
He leaves us fuller, iron-wrought and whole.
So let Time take what youthful hours he may,
My heart still kindles at the close of day.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

text.response:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Slipped silken hours through fingers barely closed,
Eclipsed the laughter, stilled the songs uncouth,
And left a face the mirror scarcely knows?
Yet memory glimmers—gold on fields once green,
Those days when dreams outpaced the march of sun.
Now shadows lengthen, but within, I glean
The pulse of hope that tells me youth's not done.
For every line inscribed upon my skin
Is but a diary of moments free,
And though he robs me, Time can't wholly win;
The heart, untouched, remains in custody.
So let the subtle thief his larcenies pursue—
My spirit claims what years cannot undo.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
With gentle art removes each tender bloom,
A whispering hand that, silent and uncouth,
Transforms the garden into autumn's gloom.
Yet in regret, the heart finds ripened seed,
A fruit more sweet than spring itself could give.
For in each wrinkle, wisdom finds its creed,
And through lost years, we learn more how to live.
Though hours may fly and soft cheeks fade to grey,
Still kindled hope can flourish in the end;
The thief that steals our dawn, ironically,
Bestows the dusk for hearts to comprehend.
Thus time, unwitting in its ceaseless theft,
Leaves gifts adornéd in those hours left.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stealthy and swift, he tiptoes through the mind,
Unraveling innocence, stealing truth,
Yet sowing seeds of wisdom he would find.
The mirror shivers with each fleeting year,
And laughter lines are currency he takes.
Yet for each sorrow pressed, some joy appears,
An understanding brightens as day breaks.
Oh, subtle thief! Pause now and rest your hand.
If you must steal the bloom, leave scent behind,
That I might wander flower-strewn, not sand,
Remembered dreams that never are confined.
For even as you pocket days like gold,
My soul, undiminished, defies the old.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Tiptoed past watchful eyes and hopeful hearts,
Turning dawn's promise to a wistful truth,
And painting silver where the darkness starts.
Yet, as each page is turned, each season spun,
The spirit deepens in its silent way.
Time cannot reckon victories hard-won,
Nor count the light that threads each passing day.
Still, memory pulses in the veins of years—
A gentle tide that carries laughter’s sound,
Transforming fleeting gladness and old fears
Into a treasure that is rarely found.
Let Time pilfer what it must from these hands;
My truest riches lie in what remains.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
With nimble fingers picking at the seam,
Unseen, he spirits hope with furtive truth,
And leaves behind a longing for the dream.
The golden summers, claiming all too fast,
Now fade to sepia in memory’s glare.
Yet Time in taking, teaches as he casts
A softer shade on what the years prepare.
For in the quiet shadows of his flight,
We learn to treasure moments as they pass.
The gleaming eyes of childhood lose their light,
But wisdom sprouts like emeralds in the grass.
So let the thief continue in his route—
Each stolen day reveals a richer root.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

text.response:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept softly in upon my window’s ledge,
Disguised in golden seasons, darker truth—
His whispers trailing softly on the edge.
The mornings crowd behind a trembling glass,
A memory’s haze, once sharp, now gently dulled;
As shadows stretch across the dew-drenched grass,
The laughter of the past, so quickly lulled.
Yet in this theft, a quiet gift descends—
Perspective drawn from loss and gain entwined.
Though youth is fleeting, wisdom gently bends,
And plants new seeds within my patient mind.
Oh, subtle thief, your treasure still abides:
The heart, unbowed, where hope and dream resides.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
With nimble fingers stole my fresher days,
Traded smooth cheeks for lines that speak the truth,
And scattered innocence in tangled maze.
Gone are the springs I leapt after the dawn,
The daisy chains around my eager throat;
Now moonlight waltzes through the lawn,
While I recall old songs in softer note.
Yet I, who mourn each minute’s clever heist,
Find solace in the amber hours he leaves—
For wisdom, like a late September tryst,
Unfolds as summer’s reckless spirit grieves.
Behold: though Time’s cruel commerce cannot cease,
He leaves me diamonds, sparkling in peace.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Unlaced the seams of every childhood dream,
And stitched instead the patchwork robe of truth
That wears me gently thin upon its seam.
The laughter echoes less in empty halls,
Where once the echoes bounced all night with glee,
And in the mirror’s glass, a stranger calls,
As memories flit soft and silently.
Yet in each thread that Time would tug apart,
A tapestry of living still persists;
In silvered hair and well-worn, stubborn heart,
A legacy endures between the fists.
So steal, O Time, your golden summer days—
You cannot touch the spirit’s quiet blaze.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Unwinds the hours with invisible hand—
From rosy childhood, racing toward the truth,
We tumble, grains of fate in shifting sand.
Where once the world awakened in my eyes,
With promise painted bright as morning sun,
Now shadow-lengthening, the old surprise
Is that the race with clocks is never won.
Yet, in this chase, new gardens gently bloom,
With patience nurtured in the fading light;
The wisdom grown from loss becomes perfume,
A fragrance sweet that lingers through the night.
So let Time slip his treasures from my store:
I greet each dawn with yearning, evermore.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Did filch the springtide laughter from my lips;
Let autumn leave its mark, a silent proof,
Inscribed where once the careless daylight slips.
Yet, in the wake of hours slyly gone,
A tapestry of moments, soft and ripe—
Swells golden, where the yearning sun has shone
And every loss begets new dreams to write.
Though shadows lengthen underneath the years,
And childhood’s simple marvels fade from view,
I gather, undeterred by ghostly fears,
Fresh wonder, as the world refashions true.
If Time be thief, let him abscond his due—
My heart remains, forever bright and new.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

text.response:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
He creeps in shadowed hush, with silent art,
He steals the laughter from our open truth
And leaves behind the echo in our hearts.
A morning’s dew, once bright upon the grass,
Evaporates beneath his warming gaze;
So moments fleet, impossible to grasp,
As we grow old within the winding maze.
Yet gentle is his hand upon the soul—
For wisdom grows where once ran wild delight;
The roses fade, and yet the seeds are whole,
Transformed by loss into a softer light.
O Time, you pilfer, yet you also give—
New dreams arise within the lives we live.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
He slips between the heartbeats of a year;
He embalms our innocence with silent truth,
Then paints fresh lines where laughter once was clear.
Yet in his wake, the garden blooms anew,
With petals shaped by memories grown deep;
The brightest joys we thought we surely knew
Are now sweet sorrows, thoughtfully we keep.
For every joy that Time would claim as his,
He scatters gifts that only age can find—
A quiet strength, a love that softly is,
A wiser look, a more forgiving mind.
Though Time may steal the blush from every rose,
He leaves the warmth by which the spirit grows.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
He plunders gently, seldom with a sound,
Each hopeful year, each radiant, eager truth,
Replaced with tales in wisdom's cloak now bound.
The laughter echoed from the ancient trees,
Now softer, muted by the hush of years;
Yet in each ring, resilience I seize,
And turn to face the loss with grateful tears.
O fleeting vigor! Chased by steady hands,
But in your wake a different beauty springs:
Compassion learned, and patient heart expands,
A gentle grace that deep reflection brings.
Though youth departs, the soul's bright ember stays—
Illuminating age in tender ways.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
He treads in velvet boots while we are still,
His pockets full of memory and truth,
He slips away with vigor, pulse, and thrill.
Yet in his passing, he sows seasoned days
Where wisdom blooms within the furrowed brow.
The world recalibrates her dazzling gaze
And offers kindness where impatience grew.
No hour returns—its passing makes us mourn,
Yet we, resilient, shape each gift afresh:
A gentler smile, a spirit less forlorn,
A heart that yields, a soul no longer rash.
So Time, take youth, and leave what you must,
For in your absence, hope and light I trust.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
He gathers petals fallen from the rose,
He dims the fire in pursuit of truth,
And silvers strands the mirror dares expose.
But in his grasp, not all is lost to gloom—
For seeds he reaps are planted yet again,
They blossom wisdom where young dreams once bloomed,
An inner strength that softly stems from pain.
Though swift his hand removes the gilded hour,
And childlike wonder fades to gentle hue,
The autumn brings its own enduring flower,
With vibrant colors tempered, rich, and true.
So let Time steal what cannot be concealed—
For in his theft, another grace revealed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

text.response:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stolen the ripeness from each golden hour.
His silent fingers—cool, unseen, uncouth—
Distill the summer's sheen from fervent flower.
Yet in reflection's glass I trace his route,
Marking the gradual wilt behind his feet.
The games of spring, now gently fading out,
And laughter echoes thin, yet bittersweet.
Still, wisdom glimmers in his ancient wake,
A torch he gives in trade for bloom once bright.
Though freshness flees, another gift we take:
A deeper grace, and memory's soft light.
So let us greet his worn and wrinkled hands—
For time transforms, but never fully steals our lands.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept quiet-footed through the corridors of days,
Pilfering innocence, swiping truth,
Leaving behind his slow and spectral haze.
The mirror once aglow with blushing dawn,
Now paints its silver script with soberer ink.
Childhood’s vibrant canvas tires, withdrawn,
Yet seeds of dream persist along the brink.
Though shadows lengthen on this fleeting stage,
And hope at times slips through the latticed years,
Still, in the heart, defiant songs engage:
Sweet harmonies that banish midnight fears.
Let Time, that sly magician, have his share—
The soul remembers youth, untouched by care.

How swiftly flows the river’s tireless stream,
Yet who can mark the minute when it’s changed?
So Time, the cunning bandit, dashes dream
From outstretched hands, our futures rearranged.
I chase the moments, desperate, breath and wild,
The laughter ringing, soft across the lawn.
Within each echo lingers yet the child—
But age exacts its toll before the dawn.
Still, there’s a bloom that waits for wisdom’s sun,
A gentle fruit that only ripens late,
And though the games and summers now are done,
The glances back are neither sharp nor great.
So hats off to the subtleties of Time:
For what he steals, he leaves in gift sublime.

How soon hath Time, sly weaver in the night,
Threaded gray whispers through the strands of gold.
He tiptoes softly, far away from sight,
Replacing heat with comfort, bold with old.
My playground fades to hush and autumn’s leaf,
The treehouse boards now warped with distant rain.
Yet—though he robs us blind, that famous thief—
He leaves behind a gentleness in pain.
For wisdom’s bud unfolds as petals fall,
And love matures within this slower breath.
No need to curse the dusk that cloaks us all—
New beauty lives within the face of death.
Time’s artful theft is less of loss, more trade:
A youth exchanged for memories we’ve made.

How soon hath Time, that agile pilferer, lain
A wreath of years upon my dreaming brow.
With covert tread, he’s led me down the lane
From sunlit fields to more reflective now.
Yet even as I mourn youth’s vanished art,
In every stolen spring, a wisdom grows.
The scars of living, badges on the heart,
Are gifts unseen, unfurling as life flows.
In shadows lengthened by his deft pursuit,
I find a grace in slowing to his pace.
The joy of loss reveals a deeper root:
The beauty in each fleeting, warm embrace.
Time may be thief, yet also kindly guide—
In every stolen year, new worlds reside.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

text.response:
Soldier, wake – the day is peeping,
Through the cracks of tangled dreams,
Night’s last shroud is gently sweeping,
Sun ignites the winding streams.
Your rest, though brief and quiet taken,
Now must yield to footsteps bold,
For peace and war are yet unshaken,
And hope resounds, as bright as gold.
Rise steady from the war-worn clover,
Feel the cool kiss of the dawn,
Your burdens carried, never over—
Yet still you wake and carry on.
Let trumpets sing and daylight glisten,
March to meet the yet unknown,
Soldier, rise! The world will listen
For those who cross the field alone.

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping
Through the canvas of your tent.
Shadows fade, the darkness leaping
Off to where the night is spent.
Stirred by lark-song bright and pleading,
Steel your heart and staunch your fear;
Duty calls and time is fleeting,
Dawn's new light now drawing near.
Boots and buckles, tarnished, waiting—
Steady hands and tear-washed eyes—
In the stir, resolve is making
Courage where lamenting lies.
Hasten forth as sunlight gathers,
Over hills the bugle calls:
Soldier, wake—the world needs answers;
Rise, for day has breached the walls.

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping
Past the weary border line,
Golden fingers gently sweeping
Dew from armor, mud, and spine.
The hush of night gives way to humming,
Stirring roots beneath your feet.
Somewhere, distant drums are drumming,
Summoning your pulse to beat.
Raise your eyes—beyond the morning
Burnished skies begin to gleam,
Promise, hope, and silent warning,
Threaded through each fragile dream.
Whatever trials may lie in waiting,
Whatever burdens you must bear,
Soldier, wake—the world is waiting,
Find your courage in the air.

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping
Over fields of blood and thorn,
Where the battered earth is keeping
Secrets of the dreams you’ve worn.
The frost retreats with golden fingers,
Winter sighs its faint goodbye,
Yet on your sleeve a sorrow lingers
Soft as smoke against the sky.
Though weary bones protest the morning,
And shades of memory persist,
Still the summons, sharp as warning,
Cuts through haze and gentle mist.
Grip your badge and sling your rifle,
Listen for the sparrow’s tune,
Soldier, rise—your hope, though fragile,
Flares anew beneath this moon.

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping
Softly round the orange rim,
Stars in silence, shadows sleeping,
Give their watch to light grown slim.
Your helmet cold, your boots still muddy,
Weapons lined along the ground,
You breathe the air, sharp and ruddy,
Listening for distant sound.
What awaits beyond the border?
Morning’s promise, threat, or grace?
Yet you shoulder ancient order,
Setting jaw with quiet face.
Among comrades, worn yet upright,
You stride into growing gleam—
Soldier, wake—the day is sunlight,
And in dawn is every dream.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

text.response:

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,

Soldier, wake—the day is ready,

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,

Footfalls echo, soft and fleeting,

From horizon’s fragile shiver,

Soldier, hope must now deliver—

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,

Long the night of restless sleeping,
Here, the dawn breathes out a sigh.

Grip your promise, face the thunder—
Beyond the hill, fate bound and steep.
Let not heart or hope go under
While the world rouses from sleep.

March in step with sunlight streaming,

Every morning grants anew.
Soldier, wake—the day is keeping
Vigil just as fierce as you.

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,
Gray light brushes bandaged walls.
Echoes whisper where you’re sleeping,

Rise and lace your battered boots,

Memory and future root
In the promise of the fight.

Stand—though trembling, find your measure—
Face the world unfurled and bright.
Each new dawn brings quiet treasure:
Faith that follows darkest night.
Soldier, wake—the day is leaping,
Hope is kindled in first sight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

text.response:

Soldier, wake—with strength unbroken,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

text.response:

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,

Soldier, rise with hope in keeping:

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'

text.response:

Through the cracks in weary stone;

The tent's embrace grows thin and fleeting,
Dreams dissolve at bugle's cry,
Yet silence hums with hearts still beating—
A golden thread across the sky.

Rise to greet the morning shimmered
With the hope that night denies;
Steel your heart – your duty glimmers
Where the campfire’s shadow lies.
Soldier, rouse! The sun is nearing,
Life and promise in her sweep;
Face the dawn without your fearing—
The morrow is not ours to keep.

Soldier, wake – the day is peeping,
Its fingers bright behind the hill;
Shadows fade while you lie sleeping,
Time awaits your force of will.

Marching boots and banners sweeping,

Hold your courage – though it’s weeping,
Memory is yours to keep.

Rise to light beyond the grieving,
Dewdrops cold on silent grass,
You are hope, forever weaving
Day from night as moments pass.

Soldier, hear the morning’s calling—
Onward now, with hearts unbowed.
Dreams too fragile for recalling,
Stir and meet the waking crowd.

Soldier, wake – the day is peeping,
Petals nod upon the field,

O’er a fate that war has sealed.
Restore the sword to ready station,
Fasten hope across your chest;
Steady hands for liberation,
Steadfast heart that knows no rest.

Listen! Larks announce your longing,

March to where the world is dawning—

Soldier, wake – the hour’s fleeting,
Though the storm and sorrow keep,
Find your flame in new day’s greeting—
Rise from fear and rise from sleep.

Soldier, wake – the day is peeping
Through the curtain of your dream.

Soldier, wake – the day is peeping,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

text.response:
At the highways of woes, where sorrow is paved in stone,
Tires hum tired refrains of journeys traveled alone.
Streetlights flicker, shadows dance in puddles of regret,
Echoes of promises unmet swirl beneath cigarette’s breath.
Cars drive by, their headlights split the darkness to the bone—
Each traveler bearing burdens the world will never have known.
Exit signs beckon to nowhere, but the miles stretch ahead,
And at each wayward crossing, another piece of hope is shed.
Still, down these haunted highways, hearts search for the sunrise,
Trusting that joy will one day emerge from sorrow’s disguise.

At the highways of woes, midnight’s engines whine,
Each lane a memory, marked by sorrow’s sign.
Brake lights like embers in a drifting, red-tailed stream,
Carrying the weight of an unspoken dream.
Windshield wipers sweeping tears from the sky,
Radio static like a mournful goodbye.
Beneath the overpasses where shadows blend and creep,
Loneliness travels fast, but hope is slow to seep.
Yet somewhere in the rearview, dawn’s golden glow
Chases the specters that haunt the road below.

At the highways of woes, we find ourselves lost,
Mirrored in puddles that shimmer with cost.
Billboards of longing flash bright on the night,
Guiding the heart but obscuring the light.
Mile markers counting regrets that we bear,
A convoy of heartache that lingers in air.
At the onramp of tears, we hesitate, stall,
Then barrel ahead, fearing the fall.
But somewhere past exits with names worn away,
Lurks a sunrise, awaiting to show us new day.

At the highways of woes, dusk drapes the sky,
As weary travelers wander, no reasons to deny.
Potholes of heartbreak riddle the way,
Gas stations flicker, offering solace in gray.
Silence clings stubborn, save for engines and sighs,
Discordant to dreams that yesterday belies.
Yet somewhere between the exit and the bend,
A wildflower blooms, steadfast, a friend.
So let us keep moving, though darkness may grow,
Trusting that hope follows highways of woe.

At the highways of woes, the asphalt runs deep,
Lined with the secrets that sorrow must keep.
Mirages of laughter flicker in haze,
Soon swallowed by dusk’s melancholic blaze.
Each odyssey mapped by the scars of goodbye,
The rearview betrays every tear you deny.
Yet pavement unwinds with the promise of new—
A journey through heartbreak to vistas in view.
So drive with your longing, headlights aglow,
Find healing that travels where night breezes blow.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A farmer's wife, both young and gay,'

text.response:
A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
She wakes to blush of dawning day,
Her laughter scattered with the dew
Across the meadows, fresh and new.
She mends the fence and feeds the flock,
Bare toes greeting the earthy rock.
With skirts that spin where breezes roam,
She waltzes through her country home.
Her hands are rough, yet heart is light,
She hums a song from morn till night.
The wheat bends low as if to pray
To greet the wife, so bright and gay.

A farmer’s wife, both young and gay,
Turns chores to songs in playful sway.
Her laughter sows the morning sun,
Her smile the ripening begun.
She gathers eggs with nimble cheer,
Whispering hope in every ear.
The apple orchard wears her grace,
Spring petals blooming in her trace.
Through weathered barns and tangled wheat,
Her steady joy finds no defeat.
By lamp-lit dusk, with hands that pray,
She greets the night—still young and gay.

A farmer’s wife, both young and gay,  
In golden fields at dawn she’d play,  
Her laughter trilling like a bird,  
Mixes with winds the wheat has stirred.  
She paints her cheeks with morning sun,  
Chasing the day till work is done.  
With nimble grace she spins and weaves,  
Among the rows of autumn leaves.  
Her joy, a beacon on the farm,  
Her cheerful voice, a gentle charm—  
No storm could ever sweep away  
The heart of one so bright and gay.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Finds beauty in each bales of hay,
With apron white and twinkling eyes,
She greets the fields and open skies.
Her laughter rings through orchard rows,

She twirls beneath the orchard’s shade,
A living song the robins made.
She holds the world within her hands,
And dances where the wild grass stands.
Life’s simple joys, her every day—
A farmer’s wife, so young and gay.

A farmer’s wife, both young and gay,
She paces through the clover hay,

With summer’s youth within her face,
And springtime heart, she fills the place.
She spins the wool, she bakes the bread,
Stars twinkle gently overhead.
Though fields are wide and work is long,
Her spirit weaves into each song.
The farm, her stage; the world, her clay—
A farmer’s wife, both young and gay.
